questions.text:
Which of the following are mechanisms of action of dapsone?
  1. Inhibits dihydropteroate synthase
  2. Inhibits neutrophil myeloperoxidase
  3. Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR)
  4. Inhibits neutrophil migration
  5. Inhibits thymidylate synthase
questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of dapsone includes:

  1. Inhibition of dihydropteroate synthase
  2. Inhibition of neutrophil myeloperoxidase
  3. Inhibition of neutrophil migration

Dapsone is a structural analogue of PABA and competitively inhibits dihydropteroate synthase in the folate pathway.

The anti-inflammatory effects of dapsone occur due to the inhibition of:

  1. Tissue damage by neutrophils
  2. Neutrophil myeloperoxidase activity and respiratory burst
  3. Migration of neutrophils to inflammatory lesions

Dapsone may also act as a neutrophil-free-radical scavenger.

Dapsone is used in the treatment of leprosy, malaria, P. jiroveci infection, and toxoplasma prophylaxis. Its anti-inflammatory property is the basis for the treatment of pemphigoid, dermatitis herpetiformis, linear IgA bullous disease, etc.

Adverse effects include hemolysis at doses of 200-300mg and methemoglobinemia.

Note: Dapsone does not cause inhibition of DHFR or thymidylate synthase. Methotrexate and pemetrexed are dihydrofolate reductase inhibitors. 5-Fluorouracil (5FU) and capecitabine are thymidylate synthase inhibitors.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme is involved in both glycogenesis and glycogenolysis?
questions.solution:
Phosphoglucomutase is involved in both glycogenesis and glycogenolysis.

The reaction catalyzed by phosphoglucomutase is reversible so that

  • In glycogenesis: Glucose-6-phosphate is isomerized to glucose-1-phosphate
  • In glycogenolysis: Glucose-6-phosphate can be formed from glucose-1-phosphate

Glycogen synthase is an enzyme of glycogenesis. Alpha-1,6-glucosidase and glycogen phosphorylase are enzymes of glycogenolysis.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The above image depicts the Ritgen’s maneuver.

Ritgen’s maneuver:

  • The right hand is draped with a sterile towel.
  • The fingers of the right hand pressing posterior to the rectum exerts upward pressure to the chin and extends the head. The extension of the head prevents the head from slipping back in between the contractions.
  • The left hand placed over the occiput exerts a downward counter pressure to prevent the rapid extension of the head
  • The ritgen’s maneuver thus helps in the controlled delivery of the head of the fetus.

Other options:

Option b: Pinard’s maneuver is used to facilitate the delivery of legs in case of frank breech presentation.

Option c: Lovset’s maneuver is used to facilitate the delivery of arms in breech presentation.

Option d: In zavanelli maneuver the fetal head is rotated to the pre restitution position and pushed back into the pelvis. The fetus is then delivered by caesarean section.

questions.text:
Assertion: Amphotericin B is given as 5% Dextrose infusion.
Reason: Coadministration of Dextrose reduces the nephrotoxicity.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both the assertion and reason are true but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false
Assertion is false but the reason is true
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution:
Amphotericin B is given as 5% Dextrose infusion since 5% Dextrose serves as a carrier for amphotericin.

Normal saline(not 5% dextrose) is administered for nephrotoxicity prevention.

As sodium restriction is associated with an increased risk of nephrotoxicity, 500 mL of  0.9% saline should be infused before and/or after the administration of iv amphotericin B.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to the OPD with a button like subareolar mass that is painless. The histologic picture that you would commonly expect to find is:

choices.text: Granulomatous inflammation surrounding ducts with numerous plasma cell infiltrates
Lobule expansion containing monotonous epithelial cell proliferation
Epithelial hyperplasia of the duct with tapering micropapillae without lobule formation

questions.solution:
Adolescent Male with button-like painless subareolar mass points towards the diagnosis being Gynaecomastia.

Histological features observed are:

  • An increase in dense collagenous connective tissue
  • Epithelial hyperplasia of the duct lining with characteristic tapering micropapillae.
  • Lobule formation is almost never observed

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman who has iron-deficiency anemia has been receiving elemental oral iron at 100 mg/day. Even after 6 weeks of oral iron therapy, there was no increase in hemoglobin levels. The patient reports that she has no gastrointestinal tract symptoms or heavy menses. Her appetite is normal and there is no weight loss. There is no family history of colon cancer or inflammatory bowel disease. Fecal occult blood testing of the stool is negative. Which test should be performed next?

choices.text: Upper GI endoscopy with small bowel biopsy
Stool evaluation for ova and parasites

questions.solution:
Upper GI endoscopy with small bowel biopsy is the next investigation performed to evaluate the patient for celiac disease.

The patient has iron-deficiency anemia that is refractory to the treatment, which is defined as hemoglobin increment of <1 g/dL even after 4-6 weeks of 100 mg/day of elemental iron therapy.

Refractory iron deficiency anemia may be due to gastrointestinal bleeding, heavy menstrual bleeding, occult blood loss or malabsorption of iron as in celiac disease.

The patient had no evidence of gastrointestinal tract or menstrual blood loss. So, the next step is to evaluate the patient for conditions causing malabsorption of iron such as celiac disease.

Iron deficiency anemia is the most common presentation of patients with celiac disease as celiac disease preferentially affects the proximal small bowel, which is the main site of iron absorption.

Thus, upper GI endoscopy with small bowel biopsies should be performed to evaluate for celiac disease.

Note: Serologic testing for tissue transglutaminase antibodies is the best initial investigation and is done as a screening test for suspected cases of celiac disease. If the screening test is positive, then a small bowel biopsy is done to confirm the diagnosis.

However, a negative test for antibodies does not exclude the disease. Therefore, in cases where there is high suspicion of celiac disease as in refractory iron deficiency anemia without evidence of bleeding, a small bowel biopsy may be done directly to establish the diagnosis of celiac disease. A negative biopsy definitely excludes the disease.

questions.text: The contrast-enhanced CT of a middle-aged woman shows a complicated renal cyst with thickened septae and solid non-enhancing nodules. How would you classify this cyst?
questions.solution:
According to the Bosniak classification, renal cysts with thickened septae and solid non-enhancing nodules are classified as Bosniak III.

Class Appearance Malignancy Management
Bosniak 1 Simple cyst: Rounded with imperceptible wall Not malignant No further workup required
Bosniak 2

Minimally complex: 

Size <1 mm with septa and thin calcifications

 

 Not malignant No further workup required
Bosniak 2F

Minimally complex:

Size >3 cm with increased number of septa

Minimally thickened with nodular or thick calcifications

 5% chance of malignancy Needs ultrasound/CT follow up every 6 months
Bosniak 3

Complicated cysts:

Thickened septa with nodular areas of calcification or solid non-enhancing areas

Appears hyperdense on CT

 55% chance of malignancy

Partial nephrectomy

Radiofrequency ablation in elderly or poor surgical candidates
Bosniak 4 Solid enhancing mass with a large cystic or necrotic component

Clearly malignant (100%)

 Partial or total nephrectomy

questions.text:
The following statements are true/false regarding shigella:

1.   All shigella species ferment glucose

2.   All shigella species ferment lactose, except shigella sonnei

3.   Shigella flexneri and Shigella boydii ferment mannitol

4.   Shigella dysenteriae does not ferment mannitol

5.   Shigella sonnei gives a negative test result for ornithine decarboxylase
questions.solution:
Statements 2 and 5 are false, while the remaining statements are true.

  • All shigella species do not ferment lactose. Only, Shigella sonnei can ferment lactose. It is a late lactose fermenter. Hence statement 2 is false.
  • Shigella sonnei gives a positive test result for ornithine decarboxylase. Hence statement 5 is false.

The growth characteristics of shigella species are summarized in the table below:

Shigella species Glucose Lactose Mannitol Ornithine decarboxylase
Shigella dysenteriae  + - - -
Shigella flexneri + - + -
Shigella boydii + - + -
Shigella sonnei + + + +

questions.text:
Match the color of the amniotic fluid in column A with the condition in column B.
Column A Column B
1. Golden color a. Fetal distress
2. Meconium stained b. Intrauterine death
3. Colorless c. Concealed accidental hemorrhage
4. Dark brown (tobacco juice) d. Early pregnancy
  e. Post maturity
  f. Rh Incompatibility
questions.solution:
The correct match for the amniotic fluid colour is: 1-f, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b

  1. Golden color amniotic fluid is seen in Rh incompatibility due to hemolysis of the fetal RBC and excess bilirubin.
  2. Meconium stained (green colored) amniotic fluid is seen in fetal distress in presentations excluding the breech and transverse.
  3. In normal conditions, the amniotic fluid is colorless early in the pregnancy, which becomes pale straw colored near term to to the exfoliated lanugo and epidermal cells.
  4. Dark brown (tobacco juice) amniotic fluid is seen in intrauterine death due to the presence of old HbA.

Related Pearl: Indications of Amniotic Fluid Color

Amniotic fluid colour Inference
Colourless Early pregnancy
Straw yellow  Term pregnancy (exfoliated lanugo, epidermal cells from fetal skin)
Meconium stained (green) Fetal distress (other than breech / transverse)
Golden  Rh incompatibility (excessive hemolysis of fetal RBC, excess bilirubin)
Greenish yellow (saffron) Post maturity
Dark red Concealed accidental hemorrhage (contamination of blood)
Dark brown (tobacco juice) Intrauterine death (presence of old HbA)

questions.text: Alkali disease of livestock is caused by an excess of which of the following minerals?
questions.solution:
Excess of selenium causes alkali disease in livestock.

Clinical types of selenium intoxication 

  • Acute selenosis
  • Subacute selenosis (i.e., blind staggers type)
  • Chronic selenosis (i.e., alkali disease type)

Alkali disease occurs when animals consume moderate levels of selenium for a period of weeks to months.

The common clinical signs of chronic selenosis in horses, cattle, and swine are loss of hair (horses and cattle lose long hair from the mane and tails), emaciation, hoof lesions, weight reduction, and lameness.

questions.text:
Match the radiological measurements in Column A with appropriate SI units currently being used in Column B.
Column A Column B
1. Radioactivity a. Coulomb/Kg
2. Dose equivalent b. Curie
3. Radiation exposure c. Sievert
4. Absorbed dose d. Roentgen
  e. Becquerel
  F. Gray
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-e, 2-c, 3-a, 4-f.

  1. Radioactivity - Becquerel
  2. Dose Equivalents - Sievert
  3. Radiation Exposure - Coulombs/kg
  4. Absorbed dose - Gray

The radioactive decay or radioactivity is defined as one nuclear disintegration per second. The SI unit for radioactivity currently being used is the Becquerel (Bq). Curie (Ci) was previously used.

Dose equivalent combines the amount of radiation absorbed and the medical effects of that type of radiation. The SI unit for dose equivalent is sievert. Rem is the older unit.

Radiation exposure is the amount of radiation traveling through the air, which is measured in coulombs/Kg.

Absorbed dose is defined as the quantity of ionizing radiation absorbed by the body. The SI unit for absorbed dose is the Gray (Gy). Rad was previously used. 1 Gray = 100 Rads.

Related Pearl: Important SI units for radiation

Quantity measured Old unit New Unit Conversion Description
Radioactivity Curie Becquerel 1 curie = 3.7 x 1010 becquerel  
Radiation exposure Roentgen Coulumb/kg 1 roentgen = 2.58 × 10-4 C/Kg Amount of radiation absorbed in air.  
Absorbed dose Rad Gray (Gy) 100 rad = 1 gray (or, 1 rad = 0.01 gray)  Amount of radioactive energy absorbed per unit gram of tissue or material.
Dose equivalent Rem Sievert (Sv) 100 rem = 1 sievert  Indicates potential danger to health.

questions.text: The O2-CO2 diagram shown below shows a ventilation-perfusion ratio curve for the normal lung. Which of the following options best describes the effect of decreasing the ventilation-perfusion ratio on the alveolar Po2 and Pco2?
questions.solution:
Decreased ventilation-perfusion ratio implies decreased oxygenation due to decreased ventilation with respect to perfusion. Hence, PAO2 decreases and Pco2 increases.

A decrease in the ventilation-perfusion ratio (VA/Q) is depicted by moving to the left along the normal ventilation-perfusion line as shown in the figure (Zones here refer to the zones of variation in pulmonary blood flow and alveolar ventilation under influence of gravity)

  • Zone 1 - Zone 1 has the lowest ventilation compared to Zones 2 and 3 but, in Zone 1 Ventilation (V)>>Perfusion (Q) hence V­/Q­ is high
    • PAO2 is highest
    • PACO2 is lowest
  • Zone 2 -  Ventilation (V) almost equal to Perfusion (Q) but slightly lower so V/Q is average (~0.8)
  • Zone 3 - Zone 3 has the highest ventilation compared to Zones 2 and 1 but, in Zone 3 Perfusion (Q) >> Ventilation (V) hence V­/Q­ is low 
    • PAO2 is lowest
    • PACO2 is highest.

*PAO2 - Alveolar partial pressure of oxygen

*PACO2 - Alveolar partial pressure of CO2

questions.text: A 53-year-old man was admitted with a history of a cerebrovascular accident. On the second day, he becomes drowsy with minimal response. CT finding is shown in the image below. What will be your next line of management?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a 53 year old patient admitted in view of a cerebrovascular accident developing neurologic deterioration (drowsy with minimal response) on the second day, and CT brain showing significant edema of MCA territory with midline shift. The next line of management is decompressive surgery.

Cerebral edema is a potential complication in 5-10% of patients with strokes, leading to obtundation and brain herniation. The severity of edema is highest on the second or third day after the stroke and can last for around 10 days. 

Medical management may not be successful in case of significant edema or infarcts involving the cerebellum. 

Decompressive surgery is recommended for patients who are less than 60 years old and experience deterioration ≤ 48 hours, despite receiving medical therapy. Hypodensity on head CT within the first 6 hours of stroke onset, involving ≥ one-third of the MCA territory, early midline shift, and a diffusion-weighted imaging volume on MRI within 6 hours ≥ 80 mL are predictors of severe cerebral edema.

World Stroke Day is on October 29 every year. On this day, people everywhere share important information about recognizing the signs of a stroke, how to stay healthy, and ways to prevent strokes. The theme this year, as designated by WSO, is ‘Together we are #Greater Than Stroke.’ In India, the average stroke incidence rate is 145 per 1,00,000 population.

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hypertension

Definition

Intracranial hypertension is pressure within the cranium above normal. Normal range of ICP is 5-15mm Hg. Levels above 20-25mm Hg are usually treated. 

Causes: Intracranial haemorrhage, brain tumors, head injury, meningitis, brain abscess, etc. 

Symptoms of raised ICT

  • Cushing’s triad – hypertension, bradycardia and respiratory depression
  • Headache, visual blurring due to papilloedema and abducent nerve palsy 
  • Focal symptoms may arise due to the local effects in patients with mass lesions or due to herniation.
  • Seizures
  • Stroke

Investigations

  • CT brain or MRI brain with gadolinium to rule out ICSOL 
  • Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in the presence of raised ICT due to the risk of coning.
  • Papilledema (as an indicator of ICT) should be ruled out before lumbar puncture.

Treatment

  • Dexamethasone
  • Ventriculotomy to remove CSF or ventriculoperitoneal shunt
  • Decompressive craniectomy
  • Surgical resection of ICSOL – by craniotomy or stereotactic radiosurgery
  • Whole brain radiation for multiple metastases causing raised ICT

questions.text: A 24-year-old RTA victim was brought to the emergency department with paralysis of right leg. Testing for cutaneous sensation revealed a band of cutaneous hyperesthesia extending around the abdominal wall on the right side at the level of the umbilicus and below it, there is a narrow band of analgesia and anesthesia. On the left side, there is total analgesia, thermoanesthesia and partial loss of touch sensation below the level of the umbilicus and involving the whole left leg. Chest X-ray revealed a fracture of the seventh thoracic vertebra. Which of the following lesions is responsible?

choices.text: Left hemisection of the cord at the level of 10th spinal segment
Right hemisection of the cord at the level of 9th spinal segment
Left hemisection of the cord at the level of 9th spinal segment
Right hemisection of the cord at the level of 10th spinal segment

questions.solution:
The clinical features mentioned in the question are suggestive of Brown-Séquard syndrome caused by right hemisection of the spinal cord at the level of 10th spinal segment.

The 7th thoracic vertebra corresponds to the 10th spinal segment.

The spinal cord is shorter than the vertebral column and therefore, the spinal segment do not correspond to the same vertebral segment. The table below shows the relationship of the spinal cord segments to the vertebral segments.

Vertebrae Spinal segment
Cervical vertebrae Add 1
Upper thoracic vertebrae (1- 6) Add 2
Lower thoracic vertebrae (7- 9) Add 3
10th thoracic vertebra L1-L2 cord segments
11th thoracic vertebra L3-L4 cord segments
12th thoracic vertebra L5 cord segment
1st lumbar vertebra Sacral and coccygeal cord segments

The clinical features are characteristic of Brown-Séquard syndrome caused by hemisection of the spinal cord leading to the damage of ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways.

Right hemisection of the cord causes:

  • Loss of motor function on the right side (ipsilateral loss)
  • Impaired sensation of proprioception, fine touch, two point discrimination and vibration on right side (ipsilateral loss).
  • Impaired sensation of pain and temperature on left side (contralateral loss)

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: A 24-year-old male who has been hemorrhaging due to a road traffic accident came to the emergency department. On examination, he had tachycardia, blood pressure of 60/40 mmHg. The attending physician ordered whole blood, however, unfortunately, it was not available in the blood bank. Which of the following would you administer to this patient to prevent shock?
questions.solution:
If the whole blood is not available then, plasma (FFP) transfusion is the recommended replacement therapy to prevent shock due to haemorrhage.

Replacement therapy:

The replacement therapy to prevent shock depends on the cause:

  • Whole blood is transfused in patients with haemorrhage
  • Plasma transfusion is indicated in patients with loss of plasma
  • Electrolyte solution is used for patients with dehydration.

However, in some cases the whole blood may not be available. Then, plasma transfusion is indicated to prevent shock due to hemorrhage.

  • Plasma transfusion increases the volume of blood and restores the haemodynamics.
  • Hematocrit is not restored by plasma transfusion. However, if the cardiac output is adequate, the body can adequately withstand the low levels of haematocrit upto half of the normal value.

If plasma is also not available, the next best approach is to transfuse plasma substitutes such as dextran solution.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following steps to be followed in breaking the bad news according to the accepted standard protocol:

A. Giving knowledge and Information to the Patient 

B. Setting up the Interview

C. Addressing the Patient’s emotions with empathic responses

D. Assessing the Patient’s perception
questions.solution:
According to the SPIKES protocol for breaking bad news, the correct sequence of steps to follow is:

  1. Setting Up the Interview
  2. Assessing the Patient’s perception
  3. Obtaining the Patient’s invitation
  4. Giving knowledge and Information to the Patient
  5. Addressing the Patient’s emotions with empathic responses
  6. Strategy and Summary

questions.text:
Theme and focus: Hypertension
  1. Coarctation of aorta
  2. Pre-eclampsia
  3. Polycystic kidney disease
  4. Cushing syndrome
  5. Chronic glomerulonephritis
  6. Primary hyperaldosteronism
  7. Pheochromocytoma
  8. Acromegaly
questions.solution:
Case 1: Hypertension, with truncal obesity, proximal myopathy, and osteoporosis and elevated urinary free cortisol level are all suggestive of Cushing syndrome. Hypertension is caused by salt and water retention due to excess cortisol.

Case 2: Hypertension in arms, with normal blood pressure in the legs, the difference in blood pressure between both arms, and delayed femoral pulsations are suggestive of coarctation of aorta. The condition is usually seen in patients with Turner syndrome, which is consistent with the clinical history of a Short nulliparous woman with a webbed neck.

Case 3: Hypertension associated with headache, perspiration, palpitations, in a patient operated for Medullary Thyroid Cancer is suggestive of pheochromocytoma. It is usually associated with MEN 2A and MEN 2B syndromes.

 

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: Clinical features of Pheochromocytoma (By frequency of occurrence)

  • Classical triad of symptoms:
    • Headaches – most common symptom
    • Profuse sweating
    • Palpitations and tachycardia
  • Hypertension (sustained or intermittent) – most common sign
  • Anxiety, panic attacks
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Pallor - due to alpha-1 mediated vasoconstriction
  • Polyuria and polydipsia 
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Erythrocytosis, high hematocrit (hemoconcentration)
  • Constipation
  • Abdominal pain
  • Weakness
  • Weight loss
  • Nausea

questions.text: The pap smear shown in the image below shows infestation by:
questions.solution: The pap smear shows actinomyces appearing as balls of dark stained filamentous organisms that appear as cotton balls or woolly masses. These masses are also referred to as "Gupta Bodies" or "Dust Bunnies". Although the bacteria is generally a commensal, the actinomyces is known to cause infection in patients who have IUDs.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient came to the hospital with complaints of sinus drainage, cough, and hemoptysis and joint pain for several weeks and swelling in the feet. On examination, he has synovitis of several proximal interphalangeal joints of the hands and bilateral lower extremity edema. Laboratory studies revealed normocytic normochromic anemia (hemoglobin 9.4 mg/dL), an ESR of 68 mm/h, and a creatinine level of 1.6 mg/dL. The urinalysis showed proteinuria (2+) and red blood cell casts. A chest X-ray was done, which showed multiple nodular lesions in both lungs. What would be the most appropriate next test?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and laboratory findings are suggestive of granulomatosis with polyangiitis. The next test performed is serum tests for ANCA.

  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (previously called wegener granulomatosis) is an autoimmune disease caused by antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA).
  • The disease is characterised by vasculitis of small arteries, arterioles, and capillaries. Necrotizing granulomatous lesions involving both upper and lower respiratory tract, glomerulonephritis, and other organ manifestations.

Diagnosis:

  • The routine laboratory investigations usually show anemia, elevated ESR. Renal involvement presents with elevated serum creatinine, proteinuria and red cell casts in the urine.
  • Serum tests for ANCA are done for the diagnosis of granulomatosis with polyangiitis.
  • Among several subtypes of ANCA, the two antibodies that are commonly seen are PR-3 ANCA and MPO-ANCA, which are directed against proteinase-3 (PR3) and myeloperoxidase (MPO) respectively.
  • Lung biopsy may be done to confirm the diagnosis. The biopsy shows vasculitis and granulomatous inflammation with geographic pattern of central necrosis.
  • Chest CT or X-ray may be done which shows infiltrates, nodules, masses or cavities.

Other options:

Option a: Lung biopsy would show histologic features of granulomatosis with polyangiitis. However, the test is done for the confirmation of the diagnosis, if ANCA is positive.

Option c and d: The rheumatoid factor and CCP tests are for rheumatoid arthritis. In this case rheumatoid arthritis is ruled out as the patients with rheumatoid arthritis do not generally present with hemoptysis, although they could have pulmonary involvement, and they would not usually have glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: The center for the reflex that protects the cochlea from exposure to loud sounds is :
questions.solution:
The center for the stapedial reflex that protects the cochlea from exposure to loud sounds is Superior Olivary Complex.

Related Pearl: Stapedial reflex

Principle: A loud sound of 70- 100dB above the hearing threshold of the patient, leads to bilateral contraction of the stapedius muscle.

Afferent: 8th cranial nerve.

Efferent: 7th cranial nerve.

Centre: Superior olivary complex in the brainstem.

In afferent palsy, the reflex is absent on both sides, and in efferent palsy reflex is absent only on the side of the lesion.

Clinical significance:

  • Can identify malingerers.
  • To differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- the threshold is decreased in cochlear lesions because of recruitment whereas it is increased or even absent in retrocochlear lesions.
  • Identify the site of the facial nerve lesion- its presence indicates that the lesion is beyond the nerve to stapedius.

Acoustic reflex decay- it is a feature of retrocochlear hearing loss (8th nerve lesion). A sustained tone of 500-1000Hz delivered 10dB above the acoustic reflex threshold, for a period of 10 seconds, brings the amplitude to 50% (abnormal decay).

questions.text:
Theme and focus: Head injury
  1. Compound skull fracture
  2. Intracerebral haemorrhage
  3. Extradural hematoma
  4. Concussion
  5. Diffuse axonal injury
  6. Subdural hematoma
  7. Basal skull fracture
  8. Depressed skull fracture

Lead in question: For each of the following patients as described in the scenarios below, identify the most likely cause from the above Answer Option List.
questions.solution:
Case 1: The bruising over mastoid process (battle’s sign), bilateral periorbital haematoma (raccoon eyes), hemotympanum, and CSF rhinorrhoea or otorrhoea are all signs associated with basal skull fracture.

Case 2: The swelling over the left temporal region and the radiological finding of a linear fracture over the anterior-inferior angle of the left parietal bone would strongly suggest injury to the left middle meningeal artery which would lead to extradural haematoma.

Related Pearl: Signs of base of skull fracture

Signs of Base of Skull Fracture

  • Bilateral periorbital haematoma (raccoon eyes)
  • Battle’s sign (bruising over mastoid)
  • CSF rhinorrhoea or otorrhoea
  • Haemotympanum or bleeding from ear

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was brought to the emergency in an unconscious state. He had a fever for the past two days and is a known case of severe COPD. His ECG is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of chronic pulmonary disease and the ECG showing different p wave morphologies are suggestive of multifocal atrial tachycardia.

Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) occurs due to impulses arising from multiple abnormal foci in the atria. This leads to supraventricular tachycardia with p waves and QRS complexes of different morphologies. It is usually encountered in patients with chronic pulmonary disease and acute illness. 

Therapy for MAT is directed at treating the underlying disease and correcting any metabolic abnormalities. Calcium-channel blockers and radiofrequency ablation of the AV node are the other treatment modalities.

The given ECG shows narrow QRS complexes with irregular RR intervals, hence it can be atrial fibrillation or multifocal atrial tachycardia. The next step is to look at the p waves. Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is characterized by at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies (shown by arrows in the image). Whereas, in atrial fibrillation, there would be no distinct p waves seen.

questions.text:
Assertion: In pregnancy, the plasma protein concentration falls despite a rise in total protein.
Reason: The serum albumin level is markedly decreased by about 30% with only a slight rise in α globulin.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both the assertion and reason are true but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false
Assertion is false but the reason is true
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution:
Both the assertion and reason are true independently, however, the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion. The fall in plasma protein concentration is because of hemodilution.

Changes in plasma protein during pregnancy:

  1. The total protein is increased from about 180g in non-pregnant to about 230g at term. However, despite a rise in total protein, the plasma protein concentration falls from 7 g% to 6 g% due to hemodilution.
  2. The albumin level is markedly decreased from about 4.3 g% to 3 g% with only a slight increase in α globulin. This causes a fall in albumin globulin ratio from 1.7:1 in the non-pregnant state to 1:1 at term.

The changes in plasma protein are summarized in the table below:

Parameter Change in pregnancy
Total protein Increased
Plasma protein concentration Decreased
Albumin Decreased
Globulin Slightly increased
Albumin-Globulin ratio Decreased

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with complaints of loss of libido and weakness. Physical examination revealed coarse facial features, frontal bossing, and enlarged hands. MRI showed a pituitary mass. Which of the following screening tests would you order to diagnose the cause of the mass?
questions.solution:
The screening test to diagnose the cause of the mass would be serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) levels.

The clinical features (loss of libido, weakness, coarse facial features, frontal bossing, and enlarged hands) are suggestive of acromegaly caused by a growth hormone-secreting pituitary tumour. However, since the growth hormone is released in a pulsatile manner, it is not possible to test for growth hormone.

Pituitary tumours are mainly classified as functioning and non-functioning tumours. Functioning tumours secrete hormones and thus lead to specific endocrine syndromes such as:

  • Acromegaly in growth hormone-secreting tumours
  • Cushing syndrome in ACTH secreting tumours
  • Galactorrhea, amenorrhea, and infertility in prolactin-secreting tumours

Non-functioning tumours produce symptoms due to mass effects. The symptoms include headaches, and visual impairment such as bitemporal hemianopia, and hypopituitarism.

The physiological actions of the growth hormone are mostly mediated through IGF-1, which is synthesized in the liver. Since the growth hormone is released in a pulsatile manner, serum IGF-1 levels are usually measured in order to assess growth hormone activity. Serum IGF-1 level is decreased in pituitary failure, defect or blockade of GH receptor. Since the low-calorie state is associated with growth hormone resistance, IGF-1 is also decreased in conditions such as cachexia, malnutrition, and sepsis. Serum IGF-1 level is increased in acromegaly.

Other options:

24-hour urinary-free cortisol and ACTH levels are useful in screening for Cushing's disease.

Related Pearl: Classification of Pituitary Adenomas with Associated Syndromes

The various types of pituitary tumors are listed in decreasing order of frequency:

Adenoma cell origin

Hormone

Clinical features

Lactotroph

Prolactin

Galactorrhea and amenorrhea (in females)

Sexual dysfunction, infertility

Gonadotroph

 FSH, LH subunits

Hypogonadism, mass effects, and hypopituitarism

Somatotroph 

GH

Gigantism (children)

Acromegaly (adults)

Corticotroph

 ACTH

Cushing's disease

Nelson's syndrome

Mammosomatotroph

Prolactin, GH

Hypogonadism, galactorrhea, acromegaly

Thyrotroph 

TSH

Hyperthyroidism

 

GH: Growth hormone

ACTH: Adrenocorticotropic hormone

TSH: Thyroid-stimulating hormone

FSH: Follicle-stimulating hormone

LH: Luteinizing hormone 

Related Pearl: Tests for Acromegaly

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male has urinary protein (+) in dipstick and urinalysis reveals oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules, which under polarized light show a characteristic maltese cross appearance. Which of the following is not a feature of the disease that this patient is suffering from?

choices.text: Treatment with ACEI/ARB can be useful

questions.solution:
Urinalysis showing oval fat bodies and maltese cross appearance of glycolipid globules under plane polarised light are suggestive of Fabry's Disease.

Excessive intracellular (not extracellular) storage of globotriaosylceramide is seen in Fabry's disease.

Fabry's disease:

  • X-linked recessive disorder of globotriaosylceramide metabolism secondary to deficient lysosomal alpha-galactosidase A activity resulting in excessive intracellular storage of globotriaosylceramide.
  • Classically it presents in childhood with acroparathesias, angiokeratoma, and hypohidrosis. The average age of death is around 50 years of age.
  • Overtime patients develop restrictive cardiomyopathy
  • Renal biopsy reveals enlarged glomerular visceral epithelial cells packed with small clear vacuoles containing globotriaosylceramide. These vacuoles are arranged in parallel arrays known as Zebra bodies which can be easily seen on electron microscopy.
  • On urine analysis, oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarised light are seen known as maltese cross.
  • Treatment is Recombinant alpha-galactosidase A.

questions.text: A 24-year old male patient  presented with a painful and swollen right thumb following a fall on an outstretched hand with his thumb extended. The X-ray image of his right thumb is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows the avulsion fracture of the ulnar base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb, known as Gamekeeper’s fracture.

A gamekeeper thumb, also known as skier’s thumb is an injury to the ulnar collateral ligament (UCL) of the first metacarpophalangeal joint. The UCL may get ruptured or avulsed from its site of insertion on the base of the proximal phalanx. Sometimes, a small fragment of the bone may be pulled off during the injury.

Injury is usually caused by a fall on an outstretched hand with radial and palmar abduction.

Patients present with pain, swelling, and ecchymosis around the first metacarpophalangeal joint.

Diagnosis can be made on plain radiographs and/or anteroposterior stress radiographs.

Other options:

Option a: Bennet fracture: It is an intra-articular, two-part fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone.

Option B: Rolando fracture is an intraarticular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone, with a ‘T’ or ‘Y’ configuration.

Option D: Epibasal fracture of thumb, also known as pseudo bennett’s fracture is a two-part fracture of the proximal first metacarpal bone.

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected. 

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: A clinician is performing the following test on a patient with sciatic pain. Which sign is being elicited here?
questions.solution:
The image shows the examiner pressing the popliteal fossa of the patient to elicit sciatic pain. This is known as the Bowstring sign. 

Important tests for intervertebral disc prolapse:

1. Straight Leg Raising Test (SLRT) or Lasegue sign:

  • Done to assess nerve root irritation in the lumbosacral area. 
  • Patient is made to lie on the back with the head extended, with hips and legs in the neutral position.
  • Affected leg passively and slowly raised by the ankle with the knee fully extended
  • SLRT test negative if leg can be raised 80–90 degrees without pain
  • SLRT test positive if pain elicited between 30-60 or 70 degrees from horizontal
  • Pain should be radicular type and radiating to the back of the thigh or to the calf

2. Bragard test (sciatic stretch test or flip test):

  • Perform SLRT
  • When the patient experiences discomfort, the leg is lowered a little till the pain disappears
  • At this angle, the ankle is passively dorsiflexed
  • If pain is felt again at the back of the thigh or in the calf, the test is positive
  • Also called reinforcement positive or Bragard’s sign positive

3. Crossed SLRT (well-leg raising test or Fajersztajn sign):

  • SLRT is performed on the unaffected side
  • Pain felt on the affected side
  • Termed a contralateral positive SLRT or crossed SLRT positive
  • Very specific sign of root compression
  • Usually positive when there is severe compression due to a centrally located prolapse

4. Popliteal compression test or Bowstring sign:

  • Bowstring sign is more specific for disc prolapse than SLRT
  • Perform SLRT until the patient experiences sciatic pain
  • Without reducing the amount of lift, bend the knee to relax the sciatic nerve
  • Buttock pain is immediately relieved
  • The examiner then presses popliteal fossa to stretch the lateral popliteal nerve behind the lateral tibial condyle
  • Tightening of the nerve like a bowstring re-induces the pain  

5. Femoral stretch (reverse Lasegue test or Mackiewicz sign):

  • Patient lies prone
  • Examiner flexes the knee and the hip is passively extended
  • Test is positive if patient experiences anterior thigh pain
  • This test is usually positive for L2-L3 and L3-L4 (high lumbar) protrusions

questions.text: Chi square test is used to test the significance of association between:

choices.text: Heart rate and body mass index
Weight of a patient before and after a treatment

questions.solution:
Chi square test is a nonparametric test that assesses the significance of association between two qualitative variables.

Among the given options, sex and type of cancer is the only pair of qualitative variables. Hence the answer.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text:
Mark the following statements as true/false regarding spinal cord:
  1. The spinal cord consists of inner core of grey matter and an outer layer of white matter
  2. The amount of grey and white matter is largest in cervical and lumbar enlargements of the spinal cord
  3. The amount of white matter is largest in the cervical level and gradually decreases as it reaches the lower levels of the spinal cord
  4. The central canal of the spinal cord is lined by squamous epithelium
  5. Rostrally, the central canal opens into the fourth ventricle
questions.solution:
Statements b and d are false, while the other statements are true.

  • The spinal cord consists of an outer layer of white matter and the inner core of grey matter.
  • The grey matter consists of cell bodies of the neurons. The amount of grey matter is largest in the cervical and lumbar enlargements of the spinal cord, which consists of the cell bodies of neurons that innervate the limbs.
  • The white matter of the spinal cord consists of ascending and descending tracts. The amount of white matter is largest in the cervical level, and gradually decreases as it reaches the lower levels of the cord. This is because the descending tracts give off the fibres as they descend, while the ascending tracts accumulate the fibres as they ascend.
  • The centre of the spinal cord consists of a canal, which contains the CSF. The central canal of the spinal cord is lined by ciliated columnar epithelium.
  • Rostrally, the central canal of the spinal cord opens into the fourth ventricle.

questions.text: Kegel exercises are indicated in all of the following conditions except?
questions.solution:
Patients with overflow incontinence are managed with intermittent self catheterization.

Causes of overflow incontinence include:

  • Detrusor areflexia or a hypotonic bladder, as seen in LMN disease, injury to spinal cord, or autonomic neuropathy (diabetes mellitus)
  • Urinary outflow obstruction.
  • Postoperative urinary retention.

 

Kegel pelvic floor exercises involve intermittent tightening of the perineal muscles which leads to strengthening of the pelvic floor muscles and decreases the urethral mobility.

They are indicated in following conditions:

  • Before and after delivery to reduce the risk of postpartum urinary incontinence.
  • As first-line therapy in patients with stress urinary incontinence.
  • Overactive Bladder /Urge Urinary Incontinence.
  • To limit the progression and alleviate symptoms of pelvic organ prolapse.
  • Fecal Incontinence

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding Haab’s Striae?

A. Not seen in juvenile glaucoma

B. Usually Horizontal or concentric to the limbus

C. Are usually indistinguishable from birth trauma striae

D. Persist even after control of glaucoma
questions.solution:
Haab striae are tears in the descemet’s membrane of the cornea that are seen as double ‘tram-track’ lines concentric to the limbus.

They are seen in congenital glaucoma (Buphthalmos), not juvenile glaucoma.

Haab's striae are horizontal or concentric to the limbus. They can be easily distinguished from traumatic striae that are usually not concentric to the limbus. Vertical or oblique lines representing tears in the Descemet’s membrane are seen in birth trauma.

Haab’s striae usually persist even after the control of glaucoma.

questions.text: Fr in size of Foley's catheter refers to:
questions.solution:
The French (Fr) measurement unit refers to the outer diameter.

As per the French system, the outer circumference equals 3 times the outer diameter. One French unit (1 Fr) equals 1 mm of the outer circumference and 0.3 mm of the outer diameter. Therefore, the outer diameter in mm can be determined by dividing the Fr size by 3.

Example: An 18 Fr would have a circumference of 18 mm and an outer diameter of 6 mm.

questions.text: A patient with AIDS was treated with zidovudine, lamivudine, indinavir, ketoconazole and cotrimoxazole. He developed nephrolithiasis, central obesity, hyperlipidemia and insulin resistance. Which of the drugs could have been the cause?
questions.solution:
Indinavir, a protease inhibitor causes the above given adverse effects.

Patients being treated with protease inhibitors (e.g., indinavir) develop a syndrome involving the derangement of lipid metabolism. This causes changes in body fat distribution. Type 2 diabetes mellitus has also been reported. This is called HIV/HAART-associated lipodystrophy.

It is typically seen after 6–12 months of protease inhibitor therapy.

 

Indinavir is also notable for its tendency to precipitate in the urinary tract, causing nephrolithiasis, unless the patient is maintained in a high state of hydration.

questions.text:
Assertion: Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) occurs commonly in Adolescent Males.
Reason: JNA has high Androgen receptor expression.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both the assertion and reason are true but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false
Assertion is false but the reason is true
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution: A vast majority of Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) do occur between 14 and 25 years of age and the predominance in males may be explained by high androgen receptor expression suggesting that JNA is androgen dependent.

questions.text: If a study sample is truly representative of the population from which it was drawn, then the study will:

choices.text: Have external validity but Lack Internal Validity
Have External validity and its findings can be applied to that population
Have External Validity and its findings can be generalized to all populations

questions.solution:
A study that is designed and performed well, including in its management of missing data, so that it is free of bias, and alternative explanations for its findings are ruled out, it has internal validity, i.e it will be valid for the particular participants it studied.

If the study sample is truly representative of the population from which it was drawn, then the study has external validity, i.e its findings can be applied to that population. However, it may not necessarily be generalizable—valid more broadly, to other people, in other places, or at other times.

questions.text: The maintenance fluid requirement in a male child with a weight of 17 Kg is:
questions.solution:
Maintenance fluid requirement for a 17 kg child can be calculated using the Holliday Segar Formula:

(10kg*4)+(7kg*2)+(0*1) = 54ml/hr

Related Pearl: Estimating maintenance fluid requirement - Holliday Segar formula

Weight  Rate
First 10 kgs 4ml/kg/h
Next 10 kgs Add 2ml/kg/h
For each kg above 20 kgs Add 1 ml/kg/h

Examples: 

1. Maintenance fluid requirement for 25 kg child: 

(10kg*4)+(10kg*2)+(5kg*1) = 65ml/h

2. Maintenance fluid requirement for 60kg man:

(10kg*4)+(10kg*2)+(40kg*1) = 100ml/h

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room following blunt abdominal trauma. On examination, he was hemodynamically stable. Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) showed splenic trauma with a subcapsular hematoma over 30% of the surface area with ongoing hemorrhage. Angiography and embolization were done but failed to achieve hemostasis. Which of the following is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The next step in management is splenorrhaphy. 

The non-expanding subcapsular hematoma over 30% of the surface area is suggestive of grade II splenic injury. These patients are managed by angiography and embolization, and if it fails, the next step in management is a spleen-saving technique or splenorrhaphy.

Splenorrhaphy is a procedure done to preserve the spleen parenchyma. These involve all the surgical procedures done to save the spleen parenchyma while splenectomy is the entire surgical removal of the viscera. Splenorrhaphy should not be performed if the patient is unstable if there are multiple injuries or extensive splenic injury. 

Grades of splenic injury:

Grade Injury
I Non-expanding subcapsular hematoma (<10% of surface area) or laceration, <1 cm of parenchymal depth
II Non-expanding subcapsular hematoma (10-50% of surface area) or laceration, 1-3 cm of parenchymal depth which does not involve the trabecular vessels
III

Hematoma > 50% of surface area or expanding

  • Ruptured subcapsular or parenchymal hematoma,
  • Intraparenchymal hematoma >5 cm or expanding Or
    Laceration, >3 cm parenchymal depth or involving
    trabecular vessels
IV Laceration involving segmental or hilar vessels leading to major devascularization (>25% of the spleen)
V Shattered spleen
or
A hilar vascular injury that devascularizes the spleen.

Management of splenic trauma:

Grade I and II injuries:

They are usually hemodynamically stable and are managed non-operatively. Initially, these patients are managed conservatively with regular monitoring of vitals, hematocrit, and serial CECT.

If the grade of injury is found to increase, then angiography and embolization of the bleeding vessel are done to achieve hemostasis. If angiography and embolization fail to achieve hemostasis, or if the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable, then a splenorrhaphy is done.

Grade III injuries that are hemodynamically stable are managed like that of grades I and II, while those that are hemodynamically unstable are managed like that of grades IV and V.

Grade IV and V injuries patients are usually hemodynamically unstable and splenectomy is done.

Other options: 

Option A: Repeat angiography and embolization are unlikely to help as it has already failed once in this patient. 

Option B: Conservative management will not stop the ongoing hemorrhage that is present in this patient. It is useful in patients who are no longer bleeding. 

Option C: Splenectomy is not required in this patient as they have a grade II injury and are still hemodynamically stable.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

Related Pearl: Indications for Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) in splenic trauma

Indications :

  • Patient younger than 55 years
  • Grade I, II, or III (in selective cases) splenic injury
  • Physiologic stability, as indicated by normal blood pressure, lack of tachycardia, absence of physical examination findings indicating shock, and absence of metabolic acidosis.

Column A Column B

questions.text: The vestibulocochlear nerve is marked in the image below as _______
questions.solution: The vestibulocochlear nerve is marked as ‘4’ in the given image, where, it emerges from the cerebellopontine angle.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS):

choices.text: Urinary monoclonal protein ≥500 mg per 24 h

questions.solution:
The diagnostic criteria for monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) is:

  • Serum monoclonal protein (non-IgM type, i.e IgG or IgA type): <30 g/L (<3g/dL).
  • Clonal plasma cells in bone marrow <10%.
  • Absence of myeloma defining events or amyloidosis that can be attributed to the plasma cell proliferative disorder.

questions.text:
Assertion: Only freshly prepared Sodium Nitroprusside solutions are administered.
Reason: Using older preparations of sodium nitroprusside causes extensive free radical damage.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both the assertion and reason are true but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false
Assertion is false but the reason is true
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution:
Only freshly prepared Sodium Nitroprusside solutions are administered because the compound decomposes in light.

Sodium nitroprusside is available in vials that contain 50 mg. The contents of the vial should be dissolved in 2–3 mL of 5% dextrose in water.

Its onset of action is within 30 sec; the peak hypotensive effect occurs within 2 min, and when the infusion of the drug is stopped, the effect disappears within 3 mins. The drug is administered as a controlled continuous infusion, of  0.25–1.5 μg/kg/min.

Sodium nitroprusside is a vasodilator that reduces afterload and preload.

Related Pearl: Parenteral drugs used in hypertensive emergencies

 

Drugs

Contraindications

Beta-blockers

 Labetalol, esmolol, metoprolol

Heart block, systolic heart failure, asthma bradycardia

Calcium channel blockers

Clevidipine, nicardipine

Advanced aortic stenosis 

D1 receptor agonist

 Fenoldopam

Caution in glaucoma

Vasodilators

 

 

Nitroglycerin

 Pericardial tamponade

Nitroprusside

 Relatively contraindicated in liver failure and renal failure 

Hydralazine

  CAD, RHD

questions.text: The given ECG depicts which of the following conditions:
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows a premature ventricular complex (PVC) that occurs every second beat (ventricular bigeminy).

PVCs exhibit premature timing by arising before the anticipated occurrence of the subsequent regular heartbeat. They display an aberrant QRS-T appearance, where the QRS complex appears unusually wide (0.12 sec or longer), and the T wave and QRS complex point in opposite orientations (discordant).

Frequent PVCs can manifest in different patterns. When two PVCs occur consecutively, they are termed a pair or couplet.

If three or more PVCs occur in succession (triplet), it is classified as ventricular tachycardia (VT). The repetitive pattern of one normal beat followed by one PVC is known as ventricular bigeminy.

When the repeating sequence involves two normal beats followed by a PVC, it is called ventricular trigeminy. Similarly, if three normal beats are followed by a PVC, it is referred to as ventricular quadrigeminy.

The ECG below shows ventricular bigeminy where every normal QRS (green underlines) is followed by a PVC (red arrows):

questions.text: Identify the grip in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Leopold's third maneuver (also called the Pawlik’s grip) is performed by grasping with the thumb and fingers, the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis. If the presenting part is not engaged, a movable mass will be felt.

Abdominal palpation- Leopold maneuvers: 

In the abdominal examination, the mother is made to lie supine and comfortably positioned with her abdomen barred. Leopold maneuvers can be performed throughout the latter months of pregnancy and during and between the contractions of labor. 

Leopold's maneuvers may be difficult if not impossible to perform and interpret if the patient is obese, if the amnionic fluid volume is excessive, or if the placenta is anteriorly implanted. 

With experience, it is possible to estimate the size of the fetus.

  1. 1st Leopold (fundal grip): identifies which fetal pole (cephalic or podalic) occupies the uterine fundus. The fetal head is hard and round and is more mobile and ballotable whereas the breech is felt as a large, soft and irregular mass.
  2. 2nd Leopold (lateral/umbilical grip): palms are placed on either side of the abdomen and gentle, but deep pressure is exerted. The back is felt as a hard and resistant structure. The fetal limbs are felt as numerous, small, irregular parts. By noting whether the back is directed anteriorly, transversely or posteriorly, the fetal orientation can be determined. 
  3. 3rd Leopold (pawlik's grip): it aids in confirmation of fetal presentation. In transverse lie, pawlik's grip is empty.
  4. 4th Leopold (pelvic grip): it helps to determine the degree of descent.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed to have Laryngeal Papillomatosis. Which of the following drugs can be used topically?
questions.solution:
Cidofovir can be tried topically for the treatment of Laryngeal papillomatosis. Usually, intralesional cidofovir is used in combination with microdebridement.

Indole 3 carbinol is an oral drug while Acyclovir and retinoic acid have variable effectiveness.

Li-fraumeni syndrome: It is an autosomal dominant disorder due to defect in the tumor suppressor gene P53 located on chromosome 17.

NF1 is located on chromosome 17 and encodes for protein neurofibromin, while NF2 is located on chromosome 22 and encodes for the protein schwannomin.

questions.text:
Which of the following features can be expected in a patient with CFTR gene mutation?
  1. Morphologically Abnormal Sweat Glands
  2. Squamous metaplasia of pancreas
  3. Congenital bilateral absence of vas deferens
  4. Focal Biliary Cirrhosis
questions.solution:
CFTR gene mutations result in Cystic Fibrosis. In all variants of cystic fibrosis, the sweat glands are morphologically unaffected.

Impaired fat absorption due to the loss of pancreatic exocrine secretion and the resultant avitaminosis A may contribute to squamous metaplasia of the lining epithelium of the pancreas. Associated squamous metaplasia of the salivary gland may also be found.

Focal biliary cirrhosis may occur in about 33% of the patients which may progress to severe hepatic involvement in <10%.

Azoospermia and infertility are seen in over 95% of males. Congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens is commonly seen in these patients.

questions.text: Identify the disease shown in the karyotype:
questions.solution:
In the karyotype, there is a partial deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5, which leads to Cri-du-chat syndrome. Partial aneuploidy occurs as a result of the breakdown of the chromosomes.

Cri-du-chat syndrome is a rare genetic disorder. Features of the condition are hypotonia, short stature, characteristic cry called a cat's cry in the first few weeks of life, microcephaly with protruding metopic sutures, hypertelorism, bilateral epicanthic folds, high arched palate, flat nasal bridge, and intellectual disability.

Diagnosis is based on clinical findings and chromosomal analysis. Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) is the specific test to confirm the diagnosis. 

Given below is a picture of the facies in cri-du-chat syndrome:

Other options:

Option B: Bloom syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by short stature, sun sensitivity, predeposition of development of cancer, and genomic instability.

Option C: Angelman syndrome is caused due to deletion in the maternal chromosome 15 or by paternal uniparental disomy. It primarily affects the nervous system. Characteristic features are delayed development, intellectual disability, severe speech impairment, and ataxia.

Option D: Fragile X syndrome is a genetic disorder also termed Martin Bell syndrome. It is the most common cause of inherited mental retardation (among the X-linked disorders), intellectual disability, and autism.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman is diagnosed with breast cancer. Immunohistochemistry staining revealed the findings as shown in the image below. Which among the following adjuvant treatments will you provide for this patient?
questions.solution:
The immunohistochemistry staining shown in the above image is ER+, PR+, and HER2+, which is triple positive or luminal type B. The adjuvant treatment of choice for this patient is endocrine therapy + chemotherapy + trastuzumab.

Positive staining is indicated by the presence of brown-colored tissue.

  • The Estrogen receptor (ER) and Progesterone receptor (PR) are both nuclear receptors, hence, the nucleus is stained brown if positive.
  • The human epidermal growth factor receptor type 2 (HER2) is a membrane receptor, hence the cell membrane is stained brown if positive.

The image below shows positive and negative staining for ER, PR, and HER2:

 

The adjuvant treatment modalities currently in practice include:

  • Endocrine treatment such as tamoxifen or ovarian suppression. It is given to patients with tumours that are hormone receptor-positive (either ER+ or PR+).
  • Anti-HER2 therapy with trastuzumab (humanized monoclonal antibody). It is given to patients with tumours that are HER2 overexpressing.
  • Chemotherapy as per the American Society of Clinical Oncology guidelines should be considered for patients with positive lymph nodes, HER2-positive disease, tumors >5 mm, triple-negative tumors, or with lympho-vascular invasion.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

questions.text: A patient is confused, opens his eyes on painful stimuli,  flexes one limb on painful stimuli, and can localize the stimulus with the other limb. His Glasgow Coma Score is ________
questions.solution:
The GCS in this patient is 11.

  • The score for verbal response: 4, because he is confused.
  • The score for eye-opening: 2, because his eyes are opening to only painful stimuli.
  • The score for best motor response: 5, because he can localize pain. 

Therefore, the GCS score is (4+2+5) = 11.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text:
Match the following Disorders of thought with the respective Classes:
Column A  Column B
Disorder of form Antisocial urges & Delusions
Disorder of stream Delusions & Thought echo
Disorder of possession Desultory thoughts & clang associations
Disorder of content Obsession & Compulsion
  Derailment & Word salad
  Flight of Ideas & Circumstantialities
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Disorder of form Derailment and Word salad
Disorder of stream Flight of Ideas and Circumstantialities
Disorder of possession Obsession and Compulsion
Disorder of content Antisocial urges and Delusions

Related Pearl: Classification of disorders of thought

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"
