questions.text: Which of the following statements are true regarding umbilical cord blood banking:
questions.solution:
1. The umbilical vein is used for collecting the Umbilical Cord Blood (UCB) which is stored in Cord blood banks that can be private, public or hybrid banks.
  2. Transplantation of UCB is indeed possible across HLA barriers. UCB has a lower risk of graft versus host disease compared to conventional HSCT from peripheral blood and bone marrow.
  3. UCB from unaffected (not any) matched sibling donor can be used for thalassemia transplants.
  4. The role of UCB in diseases like BPD, HIE where the regenerative property of the stem cells is utilized, is still under research and hence limited to clinical trials only at present. So, currently, there is no scientific data to prove that autologous cord blood is of any value for regenerative medical purposes.
  5. The risk of having a disease curable by autologous transplant is very low in low-risk families. It is only around (0.04 to 0.0005%).

questions.text: The following test is positive for identification of ________
questions.solution:
The image shows the germ tube test used for identifying Candida albicans. 

Candida species, when cultured, grow as oval, budding yeast cells with pseudohyphae. Unlike other species of candida, Candida albicans can also produce true hyphae or germ tubes. This can be demonstrated after incubation in serum maintained at 37°C for about 90 minutes. This is known as the Reynolds-Braude phenomenon. This test is positive for Candia dubliniensis as well. Another distinguishing feature of C. albicans is that it produces large, spherical chlamydospores on nutritionally deficient media.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is an not a contra-indication for induction of labour?
questions.solution:
Pre-eclampsia is not a contraindication for the induction of labor. 

Contracted pelvis, acute fetal distress and Ca Cervix are all absolute contraindications for the induction of labor.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text: Chitotriosidase elevation can be used as a marker for:
questions.solution:
Blood chitotriosidase is an enzymatic marker of macrophage activation and is elevated in Lysosomal Storage Disorders.

It is relatively specific for Gaucher’s disease as it is associated with a relatively higher level than in other conditions.

Related Pearl: Purine salvage deficiencies: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome and Adenosine deaminase deficiency(SCID)

Severe Combined Immunodeficiency(SCID):

Adenosine deaminase enzyme deficiency is one of the major cause of SCID. It is also called as Glanzmann–Riniker syndrome.

SCID patients are usually affected by severe bacterial, viral, or fungal infections early in life and often present with interstitial lung disease, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive.

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome:

It is due to deficiency of the enzyme Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase(HGPRT). It is an X-linked recessive disease.

Clinical features:

  • Intellectual disability
  • Self-mutilation
  • Aggression
  • Hyperuricemia 
  • Gout

Treatment:

  • Allopurinol
  • Febuxostat

questions.text: The following image shows:
questions.solution:
The above image is of a joule burn which is specific and diagnostic of electric burns and is found at the point of entry.  

Joule burn is a specific and diagnostic of contact with electricity and is found at the point of entry of the current. It is seen in accidents with high-tension currents. It is an endogenous thermal burn due to the heat generated in the body from electricity. These marks are round or oval, shallow craters, 1-2 cm in diameter, and raised borders around part or the whole of their circumference.
The crater floor is lined by pale flattened skin. The presence of an areola of blanched skin is seen at the periphery of the joule burn, which survives death and is pathognomonic of electrical damage.

Other important features of electrical injuries:

  • Flash / Spark burns - results when there is a high voltage electrical injury and contact between metal and skin is loose. It is an exogenous burn, keratin melts in the skin producing brownish keratin nodules with pale areola. Very high voltage currents produce massive destruction of tissue with loss of extremities and rupture of organs. 
  • Crocodile burns - multiple nodules on the skin due to high voltage electrical injury over a large body surface. 
  • Bone pearls or wax drippings - heat generated by the current may melt the calcium phosphate which is seen in X-rays of limbs as typical round dense foci. 

Other options:

Option A: Soot-soiling occurs from the person holding a shotgun barrel.

  • In tight flesh contact wounds, soot soiling, and muzzle marks are uncommon. If there is loose contact or clothes are interposed, there may be soiling or muzzle marks.
  • In a case involving a close-range shotgun injury, if a victim catches the barrel of the gun, there may be soot-soling of the hands.

Option B: Frost Bite:

Below is the image of frostbite. It occurs when the body is exposed to cold temperatures (-2.5° C), is only produced during life, and cannot be caused postmortem.

Option D: Scalding: Scalds are due to exposure to wet heat like hot water or steam (image shown below).

questions.text: An approved vaccine for a non-lethal disease A has been administered in a village containing many cases of the disease. Which of the following parameters would decrease following the administration of the vaccine?
questions.solution:
Incidence of disease would decrease following the administration of a vaccine.

Incidence refers to the number of new cases occurring in a specific population in a given period of time. It is a health indicator that is subject to variation. An increase in incidence suggests an ineffective control of the disease or a change in the etiology or environment. The introduction of vaccines helps to bring down the incidence of diseases. 

As the condition is non-fatal, the mortality rate, the survival rate, and the case fatality rate are unaffected.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: A 4-year old child presented with a history of recurrent fractures, without any significant trauma. The child had short stature, scoliosis and bowed arms and legs. The X-ray image is as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray and clinical features are characteristic of osteogenesis imperfecta.

Osteogenesis imperfecta also known as "brittle bone" disease, is a genetic disorder characterized by abnormal synthesis and structural defects of the type I collagen leading to abnormalities of the bones, teeth, ligaments, sclerae, and skin.

The defining clinical features of OI include:

  • Osteopenia
  • Recurrent Fractures
  • Laxity of Ligaments
  • Bluish Discoloration of The Sclerae
  • Dentinogenesis Imperfecta ("Crumbling Teeth")

questions.text: Which of the following proteins is not a hemoprotein?
questions.solution:
Albumin is not a hemoprotein. Though albumin can bind some metheme in cases of hemolytic anemia, it is not a hemoprotein per se.

Hemoproteins are metalloproteins that contain a heme prosthetic group. The heme group confers functionalities like oxygen-carrying, oxygen reduction, electron transfer, etc.

Hemoproteins include:

  • Myoglobin
  • Hemoglobin
  • Cytochrome c
  • Catalase
  • Cytochrome P450
  • Tryptophan Pyrrolase

questions.text: If carbamazepine is added to ongoing valproate therapy, what adverse effect is risked?
questions.solution:
If carbamazepine is added to ongoing valproate therapy, it can result in hepatotoxicity.

A combination of valproate and carbamazepine increases hepatotoxicity. Valproic acid may inhibit carbamazepine clearance and increase steady-state carbamazepine blood levels.

questions.text:
Theme and focus: Food poisoning
  1. Staphylococcus aureus
  2. Streptococcus pyogenes
  3. Enterococcus
  4. Salmonella
  5. Clostridium perfringens
  6. Bacillus cereus
  7. Clostridium botulinum
  8. Vibrio vulnificus
questions.solution:
Case 1: a. Staphylococcus aureus

Case 2: f. Bacillus cereus

Case 3: h. Vibrio vulnificus

Case 1: Staphylococcus aureus

  • S. aureus is commonly found on the skin and may contaminate food if the food handler doesn’t wash his/her hands properly.
  • The common food sources include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches.
  • The incubation period of staphylococcal food poisoning is 30 minutes to 8 hours.
  • Patients present with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramps. Diarrhea may or may not be present.

Case 2: Bacillus cereus

  • Fried rice, sauces and soup are common sources of bacillus cereus.
  • The presentation may be either emetic or diarrheal.
  • The incubation period for the emetic group is 30 minutes to 6 hours and they present with nausea and vomiting.
  • The incubation period for the diarrheal group is 6 - 15 hours and they present with watery diarrhea and abdominal cramps.

Case 3: Vibrio vulnificus

  • Shellfish (oysters), especially the raw and undercooked food, are the common source for Vibrio species.
  • The incubation period is 1 to 3 days for V. vulnificus, while it is 4 to 30 hours for V. parahaemolyticus.
  • The patients present with vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain.
  • Tetracycline is the drug of choice for V. vulnificus

Related Pearl: Food Poisoning

questions.text: A patient is found to have a normal TSH, normal T4 but a low level of T3. Which of the following is not true regarding this patient?

choices.text: rT3 levels will be high in this patient
The patient will be having a recent history of acute illness
The patient will be having a history of iodine deficiency
Type III deiodinase is active in this patient

questions.solution:
The given thyroid profile is consistent with sick euthyroid syndrome. In this condition, a low T3 is noted in the presence of a normal T4 and TSH values. This is caused due to the increased conversion of T4 to RT3.

Type III deiodinase inactivates T4 and T3 and is an important source of reverse T3 in the sick euthyroid syndrome. This enzyme is expressed in the human placenta but is not active in healthy individuals.

In the sick euthyroid syndrome with hypoperfusion, the type III deiodinase is activated in muscle and liver. Massive hemangiomas that express type III deiodinase are a rare cause of consumptive hypothyroidism in infants.

questions.text: A  pregnant woman at term gestation presents with complaints of decreased fetal movements. A non-stress test was done and the cardiotocograph is given below. Which of the following conditions does it indicate?
questions.solution:
The above cardiotocography (CTG) image shows variable deceleration, which indicates umbilical cord compression.

Normal baseline fetal heart rate (FHR) is 110-160 bpm (beats per minute). Baseline FHR shows a beat-to-beat fluctuation in amplitude and frequency ranging from 5-25 bpm. This is called baseline variability. Whenever the fetus moves, there is a transient increase in FHR by 15 bpm lasting for 10- 15 seconds. This is called acceleration. Acceleration and normal baseline variability (5-25 bpm) is a sign of a healthy fetus.

Deceleration is the decrease in fetal heart rate below the baseline by 15 bpm for more than 15s. Following are the various types of decelerations seen on CTG and their clinical significance:

Feature Early deceleration Late deceleration Variable deceleration
The pattern of heart rate fall

Gradual decline and gradual recovery of heart rate.

The maximum dip of the deceleration corresponds with the peak of the contraction. 

Symmetrical and gradual decline in heart rate.

Onset, maximum dip, and recovery occur after the onset, peak, and recovery of contraction respectively.

Abrupt fall in the heart rate.   

Decelerations are variable in respect of the size, shape, depth, duration, and timing of uterine contractions.
Time taken to reach the maximum dip of deceleration  >30seconds  >30seconds  <30 seconds
Cause Fetal head compression Fetal hypoxia due to maternal hypotension, placental insufficiency, and excessive uterine activity Umbilical cord compression

The CTG given below shows a sinusoidal pattern. It resembles a sine wave. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal acidosis.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: The factors that improve neonatal outcome at periviable gestation does not include:

choices.text: Birth taking place at a tertiary care center

questions.solution:
Exposure to antenatal steroids improves neonatal outcome at periviable gestation.

According to the ACOG, delivery occurring from 20 0/7 weeks to 25 6/7 weeks of gestation are considered periviable. But this may vary depending on health care facilities that are available. 

The factors that improve neonatal outcome at periviable gestation include:

  1. Female sex
  2. Singleton pregnancy
  3. Not being Small for Gestational Age (SGA)
  4. Exposure to antenatal steroids
  5. Being born in a tertiary care centre
  6. Absence of perinatal complications like chorioamnionitis

questions.text: SGLT-2 Inhibitors shift the renal threshold for Glucose from _____mg/dl to ____mg/dl.
questions.solution:
SGLT-2 Inhibitors shift the renal threshold for Glucose from 180 mg/dl to 50 mg/dl.

These agents block glucose transport in the proximal tubule and lower blood glucose by promoting urinary loss. As Monotherapy, SGLT2 inhibitors can cause a reduction of A1c by 0.7–1.0%, weight loss of 2–4 kg, and decrease blood pressure by 2–4 mm Hg.

questions.text: A 9-year-old female presented with a unilateral skin lesion with leukotrichia. The clinical image is given below. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The image showing unilateral white skin lesion associated with leukotrichia in a child points towards the diagnosis of Segmental vitiligo.

Non-segmental vitiligo includes acrofacial, mucosal, generalized, universal, mixed and rare variants of vitiligo while the Segmental vitiligo includes the uni‐segmental, bi‐segmental, and plurisegmental vitiligos which are classified separately. Focal, small isolated depigmented lesions that are not segmentally distributed and have not evolved into non‐segmental vitiligo after 1–2 years and isolated mucosal lesions on one site are considered as undetermined/unclassified vitiligo.

Piebaldism is often associated with a V-shaped leucoderma on mid-forehead and a white forelock.

questions.text: The surgeon asks for suture material to close the median sternotomy wound post successful completion of a CABG surgery. Which suture material would you give him for the sternotomy closure?
questions.solution:
Surgical steel is used in the closure of sternotomy wound.

Surgical steel:

  • It is a non-absorbable suture material and is made up of an alloy of iron, nickel, and chromium.
  • It is available as monofilament or multifilament,
  • Tissue reaction is minimal
  • Tensile strength is infinite (> 1 year)

questions.text: An asymptomatic 30-year-old man presents with a lesion on his thigh as seen in the below image. He returned a week ago from the US where he inspected farming areas during the summer. The best management for this patient would be:

choices.text: Reassurance as it is a fixed drug eruption

questions.solution:
The given image classically depicts the bull’s eye lesion (erythema chronicum migrans) and the clinical history is suggestive of the diagnosis of Lyme disease. The drug of choice for early asymptomatic Lyme disease is Doxycycline 100 mg BD.

Lyme disease is caused by the spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi and is transmitted by the hard tick, Ixodes. It usually occurs after a tick bite while strolling through the farms. Most of them do not recall the bite and the initial presentation is only a skin lesion known as erythema chronicum migrans.

It is only after dissemination, that the disease spreads to joints (arthritis), heart (AV blocks), and the nervous system (neuroborreliosis).

The treatment protocol for early Lyme disease includes:

  • Doxycycline 100 mg BD (Drug of choice) for 2-3 weeks (or)
  • Amoxicillin 500 – 1000 mg for 2-3 weeks (for children < 9 years, pregnant women)

In severe disseminated cases, Ceftriaxone 2 g IV for 2-3 weeks can be given. 

Other options:

Option A - Chloroquine and tafenoquine are used to prevent Plasmodium vivax malaria relapse. There are no clinical symptoms suggestive of Malaria. 

Option C - Antihistamines can be used to treat urticaria. Patients present with short-lived itchy weals, angioedema, or both. 

Option D - Fixed drug eruption presents as a sharply defined oval or round erythematous, edematous plaque. It becomes dusky, violaceous, and vesicular or bullous. It occurs in the lips, genitals, palms, and soles.

questions.text:
Match the following:
I Inferior colliculus 
II Superior olivary complex
III The distal part of the cochlear nerve
IV Medial geniculate body
   Cochlear nucleus 
  The proximal part of the cochlear nerve
questions.solution:
The image shows a BRAINSTEM EVOKED RESPONSE AUDIOMETRY (BERA) tracing.

The correct match is:

I The distal part of the cochlear nerve  
II The proximal part of the cochlear nerve 
III cochlear nucleus 
IV superior olivary complex

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

questions.solution:

questions.text: An infant is brought with a history of vomiting and poor feeding. A musty odor is noted in the baby. Guthrie test was done and it was found to be positive. All are true regarding this disease except

choices.text: White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency

questions.solution:
The given scenario of an infant with a history of vomiting and poor feeding with a musty odour is suggestive of phenylketonuria (PKU). Tryptophan deficiency is not a feature of this disorder. The deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase causes PKU. 

Characteristic clinical findings in Phenylketonuria:

  • Mental retardation
  • Failure to walk or talk
  • Seizures
  • Hyperactivity
  • Tremor
  • Microcephaly
  • Failure to grow
  • Deficiency of pigmentation (fair hair, light skin color, and blue eyes)

The Guthrie bacterial inhibition test is a screening test for phenylketonuria. This test uses a phenylalanine requiring strain of Bacillus subtilis. The ferric chloride test is also used as a screening test for PKU. Tandem mass spectrometry is the gold standard investigation.

questions.text: Which of the following does not have pharmacologic action that is predominantly receptor-mediated?
questions.solution:
Sucralfate consists of the octasulfate of sucrose & Al(OH)3. In an acidic environment, sucralfate produces a viscous, sticky polymer by cross-linking and adheres to epithelial cells and ulcer craters.

It does not have a predominant receptor-mediated pharmacologic action. It is effective for up to 6 h after a single dose.

In addition to inhibiting the hydrolysis of mucosal proteins by pepsin, sucralfate may have other cytoprotective effects, including stimulation of local production of PGs and epidermal growth factor but this is not the primary action.

Similarly, Antacids act by chemical neutralization of acidic content, not receptor-mediated action.

The rest of the mentioned drug classes exhibit their pharmacologic action through drugs.

questions.text: True regarding Galeazzi fracture-dislocation:

choices.text: Radial collateral ligament tear with interosseous membrane tear with radial shaft fracture
Interosseous membrane tear with ulnar shaft fracture
Interosseous membrane tear with triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC) tear and radial shaft fracture
Interosseous membrane tear with triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC) tear and ulnar shaft fracture

questions.solution:
Galeazzi fractures consist of a fracture of the radial shaft (lower one-third) with dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint (DRUJ).

Triangular Fibrocartilage Complex (TFCC)
The TFCC serves as the medial continuation of the distal articular surface of the radius as well as a static stabilizer of the DRUJ.
It consists of:

  • Articular disc
  • Dorsal radioulnar ligament - primary stabilizer
  • Palmar radioulnar ligament - primary stabilizer
  • The meniscus homologue
  • The ulnar collateral ligament
  • The sheath of the extensor carpi ulnaris

Other options: 


Option A: Mentions radial collateral ligament but TFCC consists of the ulnar collateral ligament.
Options B and D: Mention ulnar shaft fracture when Galeazzi fracture is a radial shaft fracture.

Note: Galeazzi # are more common than Monteggia # and may be associated with ulnar nerve damage.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: What does the following image show?
questions.solution:
The image shows the phenomenon of emperipolesis. Here, intact hematopoietic cells are seen within the cytoplasm of the host cell without any damage.

The cells frequently involved are neutrophils, lymphocytes, and plasma cells. Both the cells are viable and there are no physiological and morphological consequences to either of them.

questions.text: A person is brought to the emergency department following a blast. On investigation, a small metallic foreign body is found entrapped in the lens of his right eye. What is the best treatment option?
questions.solution:
For a patient with a foreign body in the lens, the best treatment option is complete removal of the lens.

If a foreign body lies within the lens, it is better to treat such particles as if they were non-magnetic or to remove the lens as a whole. For a non-magnetic foreign body:-

  • The foreign body on iris it can usually be picked out by an iris forceps through a suitably placed keratome incision. If entangled an iridectomy is performed.
  • If the foreign body is in the lens, a few days should be allowed to elapse for the aqueous to act upon the lens fibers. Aspiration is then performed and the foreign body is removed with the lens matter.
  • If the foreign body lies on the retina, and if accurate localization has been attained, it is removed directly by intra-vitreal forceps as part of a complete vitrectomy. Laser photocoagulation of the surrounding retina is also done to prevent a late retinal detachment.

questions.text: A 48-year-old lady was started on an ocular medication that she was instructed to take daily. She develops redness of the eye. Examination reveals a colour change of the iris and orbital fat atrophy. Which of the following medications was she likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of a patient that has iris pigmentation and redness of the eye, was most likely started on latanoprost.

questions.text: A study analyses the association of 4 risk factors with a certain disease and obtains the following correlation coefficients. Which of the following indicates maximum strength of correlation?
questions.solution:
The Maximum strength of correlation corresponds to the correlation coefficient of - 0.88.

The negative sign indicates its a negative correlation but the maximum strength, as indicated by the numerical value, shows a strong negative correlation.

The correlation coefficient cannot be greater than +/- 1.

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text: 25% of the population of a community is under 15 years of age and 15% are over 65. What is the dependency ratio of this community?
questions.solution:
Total dependency ratio in this community is 67%. It can be calculated by the folowing formula;

Total dependency ratio = (Total population below 15 years and 65 years and above) x 100/Total population in the age group of 15 – 64)

In this scenario, total dependency ratio = (25% + 15%) x 100/ 60% = 4000/60 = 66.66 = 67%.

questions.text:
Assertion: The stomach is the best conduit after esophagectomy.
Reason: The gastric conduit is based on the right gastric and gastroduodenal arteries.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true and reason is false
Assertion is false and reason is true

questions.solution:
The assertion is true, but the reason is a false statement.

The gastric conduit is based on the right gastric and gastroepiploic arteries.

  • A 4-cm gastric tube on the greater curvature of the stomach is usually used as a conduit following esophagectomy.
  • The stomach is the best conduit following esophagectomy as it requires single anastomosis and has a good blood supply.
  • However, the disadvantages include postprandial discomfort in the chest, early satiety, and acid reflux. Diet modification and the use of proton pump inhibitors & prokinetic agents are usually suggested.

Related Pearl: Replacement conduits after esophagectomy

  • Best conduit after esophagectomy – Stomach
  • Best conduit of choice after carcinoma esophagus resection – Stomach
  • Best conduit of choice after benign disorders – Colon
  • Best conduit of choice after short segment replacement – Jejunum
  • Gastric conduit is based on right gastric and gastroepiploic arteries
  • Left colon conduit is based on left colic artery
  • The posterior mediastinal route is preferred for placement of conduit as it is the shortest route.

questions.text: The given cell is a ______ and the perinuclear halo is due to ________
questions.solution:
The image shows a plasma cell, and the perinuclear halo is due to the Golgi apparatus.

Plasma cells are typically spherical or ellipsoid with basophilic cytoplasm. A perinuclear halo (also called a hof) is a classic feature of plasma cells - contains the Golgi apparatus.

questions.text: The ophthalmologic instrument shown in the image is not used for:
questions.solution:
The image shows a stenopaic slit. It is not used in corneal tattooing.

It can be used to: 

  • Determine the axis of the cylinder in astigmatism.
  • In cases with corneal opacity, the optimal site for optical iridectomy is determined using a stenopaic slit
  • Perform Fincham's Test

Related Pearl: Fincham’s Test

Also called Emsley–Fincham Test

It used for differentiating between the colored halos due to cataract (lenticular) and those in corneal edema due to glaucoma. It is performed by passing a stenopaic slit across the pupil and observing the halos.

Halos are broken up into segments which revolve as the slit moves → Lenticular halo

Intact halos but the intensity and brightness are diminished → Glaucomatous halo

The image shows a stenopaeic slit.

It causes reduced size of blur circle in the meridian perpendicular to the slit and no change in the blur circle in the meridian coincident with it. So, it can be used to determine the axis of the cylinder in astigmatism.

In cases with corneal opacity, the optimal site for optical iridectomy is determined using a stenopaic slit.

questions.text:
Ceroid Lipofuscinoses can present with:
  1. Blindness
  2. Seizures
  3. Cognitive Deterioration
  4. Motor Deterioration
questions.solution:
Ceroid Lipofuscinoses are a type of Neuronal Storage disorders, characterized by the accumulation of storage material within neurons.

In ceroid lipofuscinoses, the lipid pigments accumulate in neurons, and the resulting neuronal dysfunction leads to a combination of blindness, cognitive and motor deterioration and seizures.

questions.text: Toluidine blue staining is used in the Identification of which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
Toluidine blue is the special stain for mast cells.

It stains the mast cells violet in a blue background.

Mast cells may be difficult to differentiate from lymphocytes in routine, hematoxylin, and eosin–stained sections, and special metachromatic stains (toluidine blue or Giemsa) are used to visualize their granules.

Other Options:

Melanocytes can be identified using melan A/ MART-1, MITF, S100, HMB45.

Macrophages can be identified using MITF, SOX 10, CD31, CD68.

Fibroblast can be identified using Fibroblast Surface Antigen, Vimentin, HSP47, Fibroblast-specific protein 1.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male patient presented with painful swelling below the knee joint. On examination, there is localized tenderness over the tibial tuberosity. The X-ray image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray image shows a traction injury of the tibial tuberosity, at the site where the patellar tendon is inserted, which is characteristic of Osgood-Schlatter Disease, also known as apophysitis of the tibial tuberosity.

The condition is usually seen in young adolescents and may not be associated with any injury.

The presenting feature is a painful lump below the knee joint. On examination, the lump is tender and its situation over the tibial tuberosity is diagnostic of the disease.

Other options:

Option a: Jumper’s knee, also known as patellar tendinitis is an inflammation of the proximal patellar tendon, which occurs due to overuse injury and is usually seen in athletes.

Option c: Sinding-Larsen-Johansson Syndrome is seen where there is a partial rupture or avulsion of the distal patellar tendon, where it inserts into the patella, leading to traction tendonitis and calcification in the patellar ligament.

Option d: Osteochondritis Dissecans is a condition characterized by demarcation or separation and necrosis of a part of articular cartilage and bone. The condition is often associated with intra-articular loose bodies.

questions.text: Following a mitral valve replacement procedure involving cardiopulmonary bypass, a patient developed acute kidney injury due to cholesterol emboli. Which of the following findings on urine microscopy is suggestive of the cause of renal failure?
questions.solution:
Eosinophiluria is likely to be seen in patients with acute kidney injury due to cholesterol emboli.

Laboratory findings of eosinophiluria is suggestive of atheroembolic etiology of renal failure.

Cholesterol emboli may be released from atherosclerotic plaques either spontaneously or commonly due to manipulation of the aorta during surgical procedures. This can result in:

  • Cerebral transient ischemic attack
  • Livedo reticularis (skin mottling) in the lower limbs
  • Hollen horst plaques in the retina
  • Acute kidney injury leading to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis
  • Necrosis of the toes

Acute kidney injury may sometimes be associated with hematuria, mild proteinuria, and loss of renal function, which progresses over a few years.

Other options:

Option A: RBC casts are seen in glomerulonephritis, vasculitis, malignant hypertension, and thrombotic microangiopathy.

Option B: Granular casts may be seen in:

  • Acute kidney injury due to sepsis or ischemia
  • Vasculitis
  • Acute tubular necrosis
  • Tubulo interstitial nephritis

Option C: Calcium oxalate crystals are seen in cases of ethylene glycol intoxication, acute uric acid nephropathy and drugs like acyclovir, indinavir.

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: All of the following are true about expert witness except:

choices.text: Witness Bata may be paid to Doctors even in Criminal Cases
Has the knowledge to draw conclusions from the facts available

questions.solution:
The first-hand knowledge Rule is applicable to common witness, not an expert witness.

A common witness is a person who gives evidence about the facts observed or perceived by him based on the first-hand knowledge rule (only facts perceived by him).

Section 45 of the Indian Evidence Act defines an expert witness. An expert witness is one who has acquired special knowledge, skill or experience in any science, art, subject, or profession. He could have acquired such knowledge by practice, observation, or careful studies.

If the witness is a doctor in private practice, he may request the court for conveyance charges and daily allowance according to the Government rules(even in criminal cases). As per law (Section 312 CrPC), he or she will be paid the travel allowances (TA) by the court. This is referred to as "Witness Bata".

The chemical examiner is also an expert witness

Also note:

A hostile witness is a person who is supposed to have some interest or motive for concealing a part of the truth or for giving completely false evidence.

questions.text: The 5th disease is the name given to:
questions.solution:
Erythema infectiosum is also known as the 5th disease.

Erythema infectiosum is caused by parvovirus B19. Parvovirus-B19 is a non-enveloped single-stranded DNA virus. The incubation period after infection is typically around 4-14 days.

It evolves in three phases:

  • The first phase - sudden onset diffuse and macular, asymptomatic erythema of the cheeks (slapped cheek). Prodromal symptoms may occur. During the rash period, the patient is generally non-infectious.

The image given below shows the classical slapped cheek appearance of erythema infectiosum caused by parvovirus B19.

  • The second phase -  begins after 1–4 days, with discrete erythematous macules and papules on the proximal extremities and later the trunk.

The image given below shows a lacy or reticular pattern of rash involving the proximal extremities and trunk seen in the 5th disease.

  • Third phase - The recurring stage, the eruption is significantly reduced or invisible, only to recur after the patient is exposed to heat or sunlight, or in response to crying or exercise.

Only about 7% of children with erythema infectiosum have arthralgias, whereas 80% of adults who have joint involvement in the hands and knees may be involved in mimicking rheumatoid arthritis, and arthropathy.

Parvovirus B-19 infection may have several presentations like:

  • Transient aplastic crisis - It may be seen in patients with underlying chronic hemolytic anemia like sickle-cell disease, thalassemia, hereditary spherocytosis, and RBC enzyme deficiencies like pyruvate kinase deficiency. Patients with aplastic crisis appear ill with fever, malaise, and pale with tachycardia and tachypnea due to profound anemia. The rash may or may not be present. Children with sickle-cell disease may also develop vaso-occlusive crises.
  • Pure red cell aplasia - Persistent B19V infection that results in pure red cell aplasia has been reported in many immunosuppressed patients, including patients with congenital immunodeficiency, AIDS, and lymphoproliferative disorders and transplant recipients.
  • Primary maternal infection is associated with non-immune fetal hydrops and intrauterine fetal demise

It is a clinical diagnosis that does not require investigations usually. However, in the case of pregnant women or with other manifestations an IgM ELISA or PCR assay may be done. It is self-limited and resolves on its own.

questions.text: A young male who is shy and prefers social isolation appears to be emotionally cold and resides alone. There is no history of hallucinations or delusions. The most likely diagnosis is __________
questions.solution:
The diagnosis, in this case, is schizoid personality disorder.

Schizoid personality disorder is a cluster A personality disorder. The patient neither desires nor enjoys close relationships (shy and prefers social isolation, resides alone as in the question) and shows emotional coldness and detachment.

In contrast, subjects with emotionally unstable (borderline) personality disorder cannot tolerate being alone, and they search for companionship.

questions.text: An AIDS patient presented with skin lesions as shown in the image below. Skin biopsy revealed proliferating spindle cells in the dermis with slit-like spaces containing the red cells. Which of the following viruses is most likely to cause the condition?
questions.solution:
The above image showing red purple macules and plaques together with the clinical features and the biopsy finding is suggestive of kaposi sarcoma which is caused by Human herpesvirus 8.

  • Kaposi sarcoma is caused by human herpesvirus 8, also called Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpes virus (KSHV).
  • It is the most common HIV-related malignancy and is an AIDS defining illness.
  • The lesions appear as red-purple macules or raised plaques over the skin, and the biopsy shows spindle cells in the dermis.

questions.text: Crigler Massage is used in the treatment of:
questions.solution: Crigler’s massage increases the hydrostatic pressure and is used in the management of Congenital Nasolacrimal Duct Obstruction.

questions.text:
Assertion: ST elevated myocardial infarction is more likely to be developed in a slowly developing, high-grade coronary artery stenosis, than a mural thrombus due to plaque rupture.

Reason: In slowly developing coronary artery stenosis, rich collaterals develop over time.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true and reason is false
Assertion is false and reason is true

questions.solution:
STEMI is less likely to be developed in a slowly developing coronary artery stenosis, because there would be enough time during which there is development of the collateral blood supply.

STEMI is likely to occur in case of plaque rupture, as there is a rapid formation of mural thrombus at the site of plaque rupture.

questions.text:
Assertion: VZIG should be administered to a Preterm Baby delivered at 26 weeks to a mother who has had a rash for 10 days.
Reason: The moderating effect of Maternal IgG occurs only after 36 weeks of gestation.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both the assertion and reason are true but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false
Assertion is false but the reason is true
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution:
VZIG should be administered to a Preterm Baby delivered at 26 weeks of gestation to a mother who had a rash for 10 days because the moderating effect of Maternal IgG occurs only after 30 (not 36) weeks of gestation.

Infants of mothers with varicella during the period from 5 days prior to delivery to 2 days afterwards are at high risk for severe varicella. They acquire the infection transplacentally due to maternal viremia, which occurs up to 48 hours prior to the onset of maternal rash.

If the mother demonstrates varicella more than 5 days prior to delivery, the infection is attenuated because of transmission of maternal VZV-specific antibody across the placenta, along with the transmission of the infection.

If delivery occurs after about 30 weeks of gestation when maternal IgG is able to cross the placenta in significant amounts, this moderating effect of maternal antibody is present.

So, all premature infants born <28 weeks of gestation to a mother with active varicella at delivery (even if the maternal rash has been present for >1 wk) should receive VZIG.

questions.text: A drug label suggests storage in a 'cool' place. What is the temperature at which this drug is to be stored?

Examples for drugs to be stored under cool temperature include insulin, nicorandil.

questions.text:
The following statements provide the parameters for the modified bishop's score in five different cases. Choose the appropriate option.

I. The cervix is 1 cm dilated, 3 cms in length, soft in consistency, and midline in position. The presenting part is 2 cms below the ischial spines.
II. The cervix is 2 cm dilated, 4 cms in length, medium in consistency, and posterior in position. The presenting part is at the level of the ischial spines.
III. The cervix is 5 cm dilated, 0.5 cm in length, medium in consistency, and anterior in position. The presenting part is 1 cm below the ischial spines.
IV. The cervix is 3 cms dilated, 1 cm in length, Medium in consistency, and posterior in position. The presenting part is 1 cm above the ischial spines.
V. The cervix is 1 cm dilated, 4 cms in length, Firm in consistency, and posterior in position. The presenting part is 2 cms above the ischial spines.

choices.text: Cases I, III, and IV have favourable score
Cases I and III have favourable score
Cases II and V have favourable score
Cases I, II, III, and IV have favourable score

questions.solution:
The bishop’s scores for cases I, III, and IV are 8, 12, and 7 respectively, which are favourable scores.

The bishop’s scores for cases II and V are 5 and 3 respectively, which are unfavourable scores.

Note:

1. The station of the head based on the presenting part in relation to the ischial spine is as follows:

  • At the level of ischial spine, the station is 0
  • For 1cm, 2cms, 3cms, etc above the ischial spine, the station is -1, -2, -3, etc.
  • For 1cm, 2cms, 3cms, etc below the ischial spine, the station is +1, +2, +3, etc.

2. A bishop’s score of 6-13 is considered as a favourable score, while a score of 0-5 is considered unfavourable.

The calculation of the bishop’s scores for each of the above case is given below:

Case I:

 

Cervix Data given Score
Dilatation 1 cm 1
Length 3 cms 1
Consistency Soft 2
Position Midline 1
Station of head +2 3
Total score of case I = 8 (Favourable)

 

Case II:

 

Cervix Data given Score
Dilatation 2 cms 1
Length 4 cms 1
Consistency Medium 1
Position Posterior 0
Station of head 0 2
Total score of case II = 5 (Unfavourable)

 

Case III:

 

Cervix Data given Score
Dilatation 5 cms 3
Length 0.5 cm 3
Consistency Medium 1
Position Anterior 2
Station of head +1 3
Total score of case III = 12 (Favourable)

 

Case IV:

 

Cervix Data given Score
Dilatation 3 cms 2
Length 1 cm 2
Consistency Medium 1
Position Posterior 0
Station of head -1 2
Total score of case IV = 7 (Favourable)

 

Case V:

 

Cervix Data given Score
Dilatation 1 cm 1
Length 4 cms 1
Consistency Firm 0
Position Posterior 0
Station of head -2 1
Total score of case V = 3 (Unfavourable)

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

questions.text: Doppler sonography of umbilical vessels is shown below. Which of the following statements is false about the condition?

choices.text: There is increased chance of abortion

questions.solution:
Doppler sonography is suggestive of a single umbilical artery. The sonography shows the site of cord insert, with only one artery (red-colored). Trisomy 18 (not 16) is common in children with a single umbilical artery.

Single Umbilical Artery can be identified by the following features:-

  • Two vessels instead of three (one artery instead of two)
  • The caliber of the single artery is larger
  • Only one umbilical artery demonstrated in the fetal pelvis, lateral to the bladder.

The first image shows normal umbilical arteries and the second image shows a single umbilical artery.

Single umbilical artery: It occurs either due to failure of development or attrition of one umbilical artery.

It is commonly seen in:

  • Twins
  • Babies born of mother having diabetes:
    • Epilepsy
    • Oligohydramnios
    • Hydramnios
    • Preeclampsia
    • Antepartum hemorrhage

It is associated with other conditions such as:

  • Congenital malformation of the fetus
  • Renal and genital anomalies
  • Trisomy 18

Risks:

  • Increased chance of abortion
  • Fetal aneuploidy
  • Prematurity
  • IUGR
  • Increased perinatal mortality

questions.text: The number of visits that an ASHA makes in case of a female who has undergone LSCS, under the HBNC initiative is:
questions.solution:
5 visits are made by the ASHA to those born in a facility through an LSCS (no visit on day 1 and day 3).

Under the Home Based Newborn Care, ASHAs will make visits to all newborns upto 42 days of their life to record weight, ensure vaccination and registration.

The schedule of her visit is day 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, 42. On completion of all these visits, ASHA receives an incentive of Rs. 350.

She will make:

  • 7 visits to those born at home
  • 6 visits to those born in a facility through a vaginal delivery (no visit on day 1)
  • 5 visits to those born in a facility through an LSCS (no visit on day 1 and day 3)

questions.text: A 75-kg woman has a preoperative hematocrit of 35%. How much blood loss can be allowed before transfusion needs to be considered? (Consider transfusion cut off of Hematocrit as 30%)
questions.solution:
750 ml blood loss can be allowed before transfusion needs to be considered

The transfusion point can be determined preoperatively from the hematocrit and by estimating blood volume. Patients with a normal hematocrit should generally be transfused only after losses greater than 10–20% of their blood volume. The exact point is based on the patient’s medical condition and the surgical procedure. The amount of blood loss necessary for the hematocrit to fall to 30% can be calculated as follows:

  1. Estimate blood volume
  2. Estimate the red blood cell volume (RBCV) at the preoperative hematocrit (RBCV preop).
  3. Estimate RBCV at a hematocrit of 30% (RBCV 30%), assuming normal blood volume is maintained.
  4. Calculate the RBCV lost when the hematocrit is 30%; RBCV lost = RBCV preop – RBCV 30%
  5. Allowable blood loss = RBCV lost x3.

Blood Volume

Neonates:

  • Premature 95 mL/kg
  • Full-term 85 mL/kg
  • Infants 80 mL/kg

Adults:

  • Men 75 mL/kg
  • Women 65 mL/kg

Estimated blood volume = 65 mL/kg x 75 kg = 4875 mL.

RBCV 35% = 4875 x 35% = 1706 mL.

RBCV 30% = 4875 x 30% = 1462 mL.

Red cell loss at 30% = 1706-1462 = 244 mL.

Allowable blood loss = 3 x 244 mL = 732 ~ 750ml

Therefore, transfusion should be considered only when this patient’s blood loss exceeds 750 ml.

Increasingly, transfusions are not recommended until the hematocrit decreases to 24% or lower (hemoglobin <8.0 g/dL), but it is necessary to take into account the rate of blood loss and comorbid conditions.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presented with lesions over his elbow as shown in the given image. Similar lesions are noted over the dorsum of the penis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows an aggregate of pinhead-sized papules over the elbow of a child, which is suggestive of lichen nitidus.

Lichen nitidus is a rare variant of lichen planus, where both are histologically similar in early lesions. It is mostly seen in children and young adults. Lesions of lichen nitidus are typically described as a minute pinpoint to pinhead-size, flat or dome-shaped papules with a shiny surface. They are most commonly found over the forearm, dorsum of the penis, abdomen, chest, and buttocks. They are usually asymptomatic, but can also present with severe pruritus. Koebner phenomenon, if present, is a hallmark of the disease. Nail pitting or rough nails with increased linear striations and longitudinal ridges may be present.

 

Lichen nitidus is found to be associated with Crohn's disease, Down's syndrome, congenital megacolon, and Niemann-Pick disease.

There are several histological characteristics of lichen nitidus. The distinguishing feature of lichen nitidus is a well-circumscribed granulomatous infiltration in the papillary dermis that is surrounded by extensions of epidermal ridges and composed of lymphocytes, macrophages, Langerhans giant cells, and multinucleated epithelioid histiocytes. Usually spanning 4 to 5 dermal papillae in the dermis, this clearly defined inflammatory infiltration has a "ball-in-clutch" appearance.

Other options:

Option A: Scabies is an ectoparasitic infection caused in humans by Sarcoptes scabiei. It presents as vesicles, burrows, and nodules in locations such as interdigital spaces, forearms, breasts, and genitalia.

Option C: Lichen scrofulosorum is a condition that typically affects children and adolescents who have a great immune sensitivity to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It is believed to be the outcome of the immune system's reaction to the hemorrhagic dissemination of a tuberculous focus that underlies it. The lesions often consist of small, asymptomatic follicular papules that range in color from skin tone to erythema. are typically over the abdomen, chest, back, or proximal limbs.

Option D: Miliaria rubra is caused due to eccrine sweat gland obstruction which results in leakage of sweat into the epidermis. Common lesions form on the body where the skin rubs against clothing and in the flexures. The lesions are essentially little erythematous papules. Lesions commonly develop on the obstructed skin of the neck, groins, and axillae in infants, though they can also occur elsewhere.

questions.text: A study is performed where the mothers of both low birth weight (LBW) and normal birth weight babies are questioned regarding their intake of oral hypoglycemic agents (OHA) during the 1st trimester to determine the association of LBW and OHA intake in the first trimester. Which measure of association is appropriate for this study?
questions.solution:
The study design mentioned is a case-control study design to evaluate the strength of association between a risk factor and outcome. Hence, the best-suited measure would be the odds ratio.

Note that because the proportion of people in a case-control study who have the disease is determined by the researcher’s choice, and not by the actual proportion in the population, such studies cannot determine the incidence or prevalence of a disease, so they cannot determine the risk of contracting a disease. However, the strength of the association between a risk factor and the disease can still be evaluated with a case-control study, by examining the proportions of the people with and without the disease who had and had not, been exposed to the risk factor.

Other options:

Option A - Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates of disease (or death) between an exposed group and the non-exposed group. It is often expressed as a percentage. The terms "risk difference" or "cumulative incidence difference" refers to attributable risk.

Option C - Relative risk (RR) is the ratio of the incidence of the disease (or death) among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed.

Option D - Population-attributable risk is the incidence of the disease (or death) in the total population minus the incidence of disease (or death) among those who were not exposed to the suspected causal factor. Population attributable risk is measured by multiplying attributable risk with the population prevalence of exposure.

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Calculation of odds ratio (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
  • OR < 1 indicates possible protection (negative association) as the frequency of exposure is lower among cases than controls.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male presents with a history of decreased vision. Fluorescein angiography showed the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and Fluorescein angiography findings of neovascularization are suggestive of proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR).

Neovascularization is a hallmark of PDR. So this rules out Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy-NPDR (Option A,B).

Option C: Birdshot retinochoroidopathy is an idiopathic bilateral chorioretinitis characterized by creamy yellow spots of chorioretinal hypopigmentation resembling a birdshot scatter. It most commonly affects middle aged females who are HLA-A29 positive.

PDR is most common in patients with Type Ⅰ diabetes after a period of 15-20 years and is characterized by proliferation of new vessels at the optic disc (NVD) or elsewhere in the fundus (NVE).

( NVD- neovascularization at the optic disc ; NVE-neovascularization elsewhere in the fundus )

Complications of PDR include recurrent vitreous hemorrhage, tractional retinal detachment and pre retinal hemorrhages.

It is treated by administration of Anti-VEGF drugs followed by pan retinal photocoagulation which destroys the hypoxic retina that has been producing the vasoformative factors responsible for neovascularization.

Duration of diabetes mellitus is the most important factor for the development of diabetic retinopathy.

Ophthalmoscopic features of NPDR include:

  • Microaneurysms: due to loss of pericytes around the capillaries
  • Retinal hemorrhages: both superficial (flame shaped) and deep (dot & blot) hemorrhages.
  • Hard exudates: composed of lipoproteins and lipid laden macrophages. They are yellow waxy looking and arranged in clumps or circinate patterns.
  • Cotton wool spots: which are small whitish fluffy lesions which represent areas of nerve infarct.
  • Intra retinal microvascular abnormalities(IRMA): are arteriovenous shunts in retina
  • Venous abnormalities such as beading,looping and dilatation.

The below given image is that of Hard Exudates.

Related Pearl: Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study (ETDRS) classification

Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR):

  • Mild NPDR
    • At least one microaneurysm must be present
  • Moderate NPDR
    • Microaneurysms/intraretinal hemorrhage in 2 or 3 quadrants
    • Early mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)
    • Hard exudates and cotton-wool spots may or may not be present
  • Severe NPDR - any one of the following (4-2-1 rule)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes
  • Very severe NPDR - any two of the following (4-2-1)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR):

  • PDR without high-risk characteristics (Early PDR)
    • Early neovascularization at the optic disc (NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere (NVE)
  • PDR with high-risk characteristics as follows
    • NVD < 1/4 disc area with vitreous hemorrhage (VH) or preretinal hemorrhage (PRH)
    • NVD 1/4 to 1/3 of disc area with or without VH or PRH
    • NVE > 1/2 disc area with VH or PRH

Clinically significant macular edema: 1 of the following 3 criteria are present on slit-lamp examination with 90D lens

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 micron of the center of the fovea.
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 micron of the centre of fovea associated with adjacent retinal thickening.
  • Development of a zone of retinal thickening one disc diameter or larger in size. At least a part of this should be within one disc diameter of the foveal center.

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

  • Persistent vitreous hemorrhage
  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Neovascular glaucoma

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with ascending muscle weakness for 2 days. On examination, the limb is flaccid.  Similar episodes were reported in the past, usually after prolonged exercise. What investigation should be done first?
questions.solution:
Flaccid ascending paralysis can be seen in case of hypokalemia. It causes periodic paralysis. Hence, serum potassium levels should be checked first.

Hypokalemic Periodic Paralysis:

  • This is an autosomal dominant disorder with onset in adolescence.
  • Males are more often affected because of decreased penetrance in females.
  • Two types:
    • Type 1 with mutation in voltage sensitive, skeletal muscle calcium channel gene CALCL1A3.
    • Type 2 with mutation in voltage sensitive sodium channel gene SCN4A.
  • Attacks are often provoked by meals high in carbohydrates or sodium and may accompany rest following prolonged exercise.
  • Weakness usually affects proximal limb muscles more than distal.
  • Ocular and bulbar muscles are less likely to be affected.
  • Respiratory muscles are usually spared, but when they are involved, the condition may prove fatal.
  • Weakness may take as long as 24 hours to resolve.
  • Life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias related to hypokalemia may occur during attacks.
  • As a late complication, patients commonly develop severe, disabling proximal lower extremity weakness.

Diagnosis:

  • A low serum potassium level during an attack, excluding secondary causes, establishes the diagnosis.
  • In the midst of an attack of weakness, motor conduction studies may demonstrate reduced amplitudes, whereas EMG may show electrical silence in severely weak muscles.
  • In between attacks, the EMG and routine NCS are normal. However, a long exercise NCS test may demonstrate decrementing amplitudes.

Treatment:

Mild attacks usually do not require medical treatment. However, severe attacks of weakness can be improved by the administration of potassium. Oral KCl (0.2–0.4 mmol/kg) can be given every 30 min. Only rarely is IV therapy necessary (e.g., when swallowing problems or vomiting is present).

The long-term goal of therapy is to avoid attacks. Patients should be made aware of the importance of a low-carbohydrate, low-sodium diet, and consequences of intense exercise.

Prophylactic administration of acetazolamide or dichlorphenamide can reduce attacks of periodic weakness. However, in patients with HypoKPP type 2, attacks of weakness can be exacerbated with these medications.

questions.text:
Assertion: In cases where there is an obstruction or injury to the thoracic duct, the level of lesion determines the side of pleural effusion.
Reason: The thoracic duct crosses the midline from left to right at the level of fourth thoracic vertebral body.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true and reason is false
Assertion is false and reason is true
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution:
The assertion is true but reason is false, as the thoracic duct crosses the midline from right to left at the level of the fifth thoracic vertebral body.

  • Thoracic duct enters the thorax through the aortic hiatus in the diaphragm at the level of the twelfth thoracic vertebra. At this level the thoracic duct lies posterior to the aorta.
  • Initially the thoracic duct ascends through the posterior mediastinum to the right of the midline between the thoracic aorta and azygous vein.
  • At the level of the fifth thoracic vertebra the thoracic duct crosses and moves to the left of the midline to enter the superior mediastinum.

Clinical relevance: Depending on whether the obstruction of the thoracic duct is below or above the level of the fifth thoracic vertebra the pleural effusion is either right or left sided, respectively. Chylothorax refers to the condition in which, there is accumulation of lymphatic fluid in the pleural cavity.

questions.text:
Assertion: Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle and the early part of distal tubule are called diluting segment.
Reason: The diluting segment reabsorbs sodium and is impermeable to water

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true and reason is false
Assertion is false and reason is true
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution:
Sodium is reabsorbed in the thick ascending limb of the loop of henle by secondary active transport facilitated by Na–K–2Cl cotransporter.

Also, the thick ascending limb and early part of distal tubule are impermeable to water.

As a result, the fluid that enters the early part of the distal tubule is hypotonic.

Due to these reasons, the thick ascending limb and the early part of distal tubule are called the diluting segment.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about partograph?

choices.text: The alert line is drawn 4 hours to the right and parallel to the action line
Blood pressure and pulse are recorded every hour
In normal labor, the cervicograph should be either on the alert line or to the left of it
In induced labor, zero time is the time of admission in the labor ward

questions.solution:
In normal labor, the cervicograph should be either on the alert line or to the left of it.

Other options:

Option a: The action line is drawn 4 hours to the right and parallel to the alert line.

Option b: Blood pressure is recorded every 4 hours and pulse is recorded every 30 minutes.

Option d: The zero time is the time of admission in spontaneous labor, and time of induction in induced labor.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: A patient presents with Fever with chills and Rigors. He gives a history of swelling of the right eye that has now spread to the left eye as well. All this was preceded by a ‘Boil’ over the philtrum over a week back. Which of the following is not a finding you would expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history is suggestive of Cavernous sinus thrombosis. Mydriasis, not miosis, would be the expected finding here.

Cavernous Sinus thrombosis affects III, IV and VI Cranial nerves.

CN III involvement results in Ptosis and Mydriasis.

CN VI involvement results in Lateral Gaze Palsy.

CN IV is the last to be involved which together with the above lesions result in complete ophthalmoplegia.

questions.text: Maintenance dose of a drug primarily depends upon _________
questions.solution:
The maintenance dose of a drug primarily depends upon clearance (or plasma half-life) of the drug. It is the dose that has to be repeated at specified intervals after the attainment of the target plasma concentration, in order to maintain it.

Other options:

Option A: The loading dose of the drug is primarily dependent on the volume of distribution. 

Options C and D: Volume of distribution (Vd) refers to the volume that would accommodate the entire drug in the body if the concentration was the same as in plasma. Vd is governed by the lipid solubility and charge of the drug, the degree of the plasma protein binding, and the affinity of the drug for the different tissues of the body.  A low Vd is seen with drugs that have extensive plasma protein binding and vice versa.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man was brought with a high-grade fever, productive cough, and confusion for the last 2 days. His vitals and chest radiograph are given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

Temperature: 102°F

Pulse rate: 130 bpm

BP: 86/58 mmHg

Respiratory rate: 32/min

choices.text: Start oral antibiotics and send the patient home
Admit the patient in non-ICU setting and insert intercostal drainage tube
Admit the patient in non-ICU setting and start IV antibiotics
Admit the patient in ICU and start IV antibiotics

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with fever and productive cough and the chest radiograph showing lobar consolidation point to a diagnosis of pneumonia. Since this patient's CURB-65 score is at least 3 (1 point each for confusion, BP <90/60 mmHg, and respiratory rate >30/min), the most appropriate management would be ICU admission and starting IV antibiotics.

Once the diagnosis of pneumonia is made, the next step in management is to determine the site of care for the patient. To identify the patients that require in-patient and ICU management, CURB-65 score is used. It includes:

  • Confusion
  • Urea ≥17 mg/dL
  • Respiratory rate ≥30/min
  • Blood pressure: SBP ≤90mmHg or DBP ≤60 mmHg
  • Age ≥ 65 years

1 point is given for the presence of each of the above. The total score determines the site of care, as shown below:

Total Score Decision
0 Outpatient treatment
1 or 2 Inpatient treatment in non-ICU setting
≥3 Inpatient treatment in ICU setting

 

Related Pearl: Empirical Antibiotic Treatment of Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP)

  • Respiratory Fluoroquinolone - Levofloxacin* / Moxifloxacin / (Gemifloxacin - only outpatient) 
  • Ciprofloxacin*

    • Ampicillin / Ceftriaxone / Cefotaxime / Ertapenem
  • Inpatient, ICU (IV)

  • Anti-pseudomonal β-lactam (IV) 
    • Piperacillin-Tazobactam / Cefepime / Imipenem / Meropenem 

Aminoglycoside - Amikacin / Tobramycin

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is the major product of the fetal adrenal glands?
questions.solution:
The major steroid products of the fetal adrenal gland are DHEA (dehydroepiandrosterone) and DHEA-S.

They serve as important substrates for estrogen synthesis in the placenta.

The fetal-adrenal-placental axis is vital for normal childbirth. Placental corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) stimulates the fetal adrenal gland to produce DHEA-S and cortisol. Cortisol further stimulates the production of placental CRH, creating a positive feedback loop that enhances adrenal steroid hormone production.

The steroid products released by the fetal adrenal gland have effects on the placenta and membranes. These effects contribute to transforming the myometrium from a quiescent to a contractile state. 

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia is an autosomal recessive condition in which cortisol synthesis in the adrenal gland is affected. Cortisol deficiency increases the secretion of ACTH, which leads to adrenocortical hyperplasia and overproduction of intermediate metabolites.

questions.text:
Which of the following is incorrectly matched?

A - Diamnionic, dichorionic separate

B - Diamnionic, dichorionic fused

C - Diamnionic, monochorionic

choices.text: All three (A, B, and C) are correct

questions.solution:
All three images (A, B, and C) are correctly matched.

  • Image A – Represents Diamnionic, Dichorionic – separated placentation. Separation of the first two blastomeres results in separate implantation sites.
  • Image B - Represents Diamnionic, dichorionic - fused placentation in twins. Here the chorionic membranes are fused but the fetuses occupy separate choria.
  • Image C – Represents Diamnionic, Monochorionic placentation. Reduplication of the inner cell mass can result in a single placenta and chorionic sacs but separate amniotic cavities.
