questions.text: Which of the following patients requires antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent infective endocarditis?

choices.text: A 28-year-old man with successful repair of a cyanotic congenital heart defect 26 years ago, undergoing tooth extraction
A 30-year-old woman with a prosthetic aortic valve, undergoing replantation of the avulsed teeth
A 50-year-old woman who received a prosthetic mitral valve one year ago undergoing a screening colonoscopy
A 23-year-old man with no history of cardiovascular disease undergoing routine dental cleaning

questions.solution:
A prosthetic heart valve is one of the indications for antibiotic prophylaxis in patients undergoing dental procedures.

The American Heart Association and European Cardiac Society have recommended antibiotic prophylaxis for patients undergoing invasive dental procedures that involve the manipulation of gingival tissue or periapical region or perforation of the oral mucosa when performed on patients with high-risk cardiac lesions.

Some invasive dental procedures:

  • Tooth extraction
  • Periodontal surgery, subgingival scaling, and root planing
  • Replantation of avulsed teeth
  • Other surgical procedures such as implant placement or apicoectomy

High-risk cardiac lesions:

  • Prosthetic heart valves or prosthetic material used for valve repair    
  • History of endocarditis
  • Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, including palliative shunts or conduits.
  • Completely repaired congenital heart defects during the first 6 months after repair.
  • Incompletely repaired congenital heart disease with residual shunt or valvular regurgitation
  • Surgical or transcatheter pulmonary artery valve or conduit placement.
  • Valvulopathy developing after cardiac transplantation (recommended only by the American Heart Association)

Antibiotic prophylaxis is not recommended for patients undergoing gastrointestinal or genitourinary procedures; however, if there is a genitourinary tract infection, the infection is to be treated prior to the procedure.

Other options:

Option A: Antibiotic prophylaxis is indicated if the invasive dental procedure is done only within 6 months of complete repair. As the patient has undergone successful repair of the defect 26 years ago, antibiotic prophylaxis is not needed.

Option C: Antibiotic prophylaxis is not required for a screening colonoscopy (gastrointestinal procedure).

Option D: Dental cleaning does not routinely need antibiotic prophylaxis in patients without a history of cardiac disease.

Related Pearl: Cardiac conditions requiring antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis

High risk cardiac conditions for development of Infective endocarditis and require antibiotic prophylaxis are:

  • Prosthetic valves
  • History of infective endocarditis
  • Few congenital heart diseases which include:
    • Unrepaired cyanotic CHD, including palliative shunts and conduit
    • Completely repaired congenital heart defect with prosthetic material or device, whether placed by surgery or by catheter intervention, during the first 6 months after the procedure
    • Repaired CHD with residual defects at the site or adjacent to the site of a prosthetic patch or prosthetic device
  • Cardiac transplantation recipients with cardiac valvular disease

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with abnormal uterine bleeding. The images below show the transverse section of the uterus and the histology of the specimen. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The gross specimen shows thickened myometrium with spongy, trabeculated surface, with focal areas of haemorrhage. The H&E stained specimen shows endometrial glands and the surrounding stroma within the uterine myometrium. These findings are suggestive of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis is a condition caused by the ingrowth of the endometrial tissue into the uterine wall. The presence of endometrial glands and stroma with the uterine myometrium eventually leads to the thickening of the uterine wall.

Patients present with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB), dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia. Diagnosis is usually made with transvaginal ultrasonography (TVS) or MR imaging. Hysterectomy is the definitive treatment.

questions.text: The cell bodies of the serotonergic neurons projecting to the dorsal horn of the spinal cord are located in ___________
questions.solution:
The serotonin is released by the neurons in the nucleus raphe magnus, which is part of the analgesia pathway.

Analgesia pathway:

The first-order neurons from the periaqueductal grey project to two groups of neurons in the brain stem:

  • The serotonergic neurons in the nucleus raphe magnus
  • Catecholaminergic neurons in the rostral ventromedial medulla.

The second-order neurons from these two groups, project to the dorsal horn of the spinal cord, where they release serotonin and norepinephrine respectively.

The serotonin and norepinephrine released may directly inhibit the dorsal horn or indirectly through the enkephalin releasing interneurons.

Note: Pontine neurons from locus cereuleus are also a component of the descending pain modulating pathway and exert their analgesic effect by the release of norepinephrine in the dorsal horn.

questions.text:
Which of the following tumors are radiosensitive?
  1. Osteosarcoma
  2. Ewing’s sarcoma
  3. Adamantinoma
  4. Multiple myeloma
questions.solution:
Ewing’s sarcoma and multiple myeloma are radiosensitive tumors.

All malignant primary bone tumors are radioresistant, except small blue cell tumors like:

  • Multiple myeloma
  • Lymphoma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma

All carcinomas metastatic to bone are radiosensitive, except metastasis from renal cell carcinoma which is radioresistant.

Related Pearl: Important radiosenstive and radioresistant bone tumours

Radiosensitive tumors:

  1. Metastasis (except metastasis from renal cell carcinoma which is radioresistant)
  2. Ewing's sarcoma
  3. Multiple myeloma
  4. Lymphoma

Radioresistant tumors:

  1. Osteosarcoma
  2. Chondrosarcoma
  3. Fibrosarcoma
  4. Malignant fibrous histiocytoma

questions.text: The action of 5-lipo-oxygenase (5-LOX) on arachidonic acid (AA) produces a potent non-cysteinyl factor that plays a role in the chemotaxis and adhesion of neutrophils. What is this factor?
questions.solution:
LTB4 is a potent chemotactic agent and activator of neutrophils that causes the aggregation and adhesion of the cells to venular endothelium, generation of ROS, and release of lysosomal enzymes.

The cysteinyl-containing leukotrienes LTC4, LTD4, and LTE4 cause intense vasoconstriction, bronchospasm (important in asthma), and increased permeability of venules.

Leukotrienes are more potent than histamine in increasing vascular permeability and causing bronchospasm.

Related Pearl: Various actions of Principal Mediators of Inflammation

Histamine Vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, endothelial activation
Prostaglandins Vasodilation, pain, fever
Leukotrienes Increased vascular permeability, chemotaxis, leukocyte adhesion, and activation
Cytokines (TNF, IL-1, IL-6)

Local: endothelial activation (expression of adhesion molecules).

Systemic: fever, metabolic abnormalities, hypotension (shock)
Chemokines Chemotaxis, leukocyte activation
Platelet-activating factor Vasoconstriction, Vasodilation (at low concentration), increased vascular permeability, leukocyte adhesion, chemotaxis, degranulation, oxidative burst
Complement Leukocyte chemotaxis and activation, direct target killing (membrane attack complex), vasodilation (mast cell stimulation)
Kinins Increased vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction, vasodilation, pain

Note: Thromboxane A2 (TXA2) is a prostaglandin, which is a potent vasoconstrictor

Leukotrienes Mast cells, leukocytes

questions.text: Community based collective antibiotic therapy for trachoma can be stopped when the prevalence of _________
questions.solution:
Community based collective antibiotic therapy for trachoma can be stopped when the prevalence of TF<5%.

The target set by WHO for trachoma is that the prevalence of TF in children aged 1 to 9 should be less than 5%, and the threshold of collective treatment for trachoma should be set at 10%. When the prevalence of TF is lower than 5%, community-based collective antibiotic therapy could be ceased. However, surgery for trachomatous trichiasis and improvement of hygiene should continue.

Elimination of trachoma as a public health problem is defined as:

  1. A prevalence of trachomatous trichiasis “unknown to the health system” of <0.2% in adults aged ≥15 years (approximately 1 case per 1000 total population)
  2. A prevalence of trachomatous inflammation—follicular in children aged 1–9 years of <5%, sustained for at least two years in the absence of ongoing antibiotic mass treatment, in each formerly endemic district
  3. The existence of a system able to identify and manage incident trachomatous trichiasis cases, using defined strategies, with evidence of appropriate financial resources to implement those strategies.

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

questions.text: A patient presents with ptosis and restricted ocular movements that have gotten progressively worse over a period of time. There is no exacerbation or remission. Initially, the upgaze was involved with subsequent lateral gaze involvement. The patient does not complain of diplopia and the pupils are not involved. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The classical presentation of ptosis with progressively declining ocular movement is characteristic of chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO).

CPEO may occur in isolation, in association with Kearns-Sayre syndrome (mitochondrial myopathy associated with mitochondrial DNA deletions), or oculopharyngeal dystrophy.

Isolated CPEO usually presents with bilateral ptosis as the first sign. It may be asymmetrical. It usually begins in young adulthood and is typically characterized by a progressive course without remission or exacerbation. At first, only the upgaze is involved, and later, the lateral gaze is also affected. Since the loss of eye movement is symmetrical, diplopia is rare. Pupils are not involved.

Electromyography shows myotonic and myopathic potentials and serum creatine kinase is elevated.

Treatment involves exercise and the prevention of contractures. A minority of patients with diplopia may benefit from surgery.

Other options:

Options A and D- In cranial nerve palsies, there would be associated diplopia.

Option C- In ocular myasthenia gravis, diplopia is very commonly seen.

questions.text:
Theme and focus: Type of abortion

Answer Option list:

a.   Complete abortion

b.   Incomplete abortion

c.    Missed abortion

d.   Threatened abortion

e.   Inevitable abortion

f.    Recurrent abortion

 

For each of the following patients as described in the scenarios below, identify the diagnosis from the above Answer Option List.
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis of the clinical scenarios given above are as follows:

Case 1: d) Threatened abortion

Case 2: e) Inevitable abortion

Case 3: c) Missed abortion

Case 4: a) Complete abortion

Types of spontaneous abortion:

Case 1: Threatened abortion:

  • The patient presents with vaginal bleeding usually in the first trimester.
  • In most cases, there is no pain. However, in some individuals, dull aching pain in the lower abdomen may be present.
  • There is no loss of fetal or placental tissue.
  • On examination, the cervix is closed.
  • About 25-50% of the patients with threatened abortion may have a loss of pregnancy. In others, there may be a risk of preterm birth.

Case 2: Inevitable abortion:

  • The patient presents with vaginal bleeding and cramp-like abdominal pain.
  • There is no loss of fetal or placental tissue yet.
  • On examination, the cervix is partially dilated.
  • In these cases, abortion is inevitable and will occur. 

Case 3: Missed abortion:

  • In this condition, there is intrauterine death of the fetus and the dead fetus is retained in the uterus for more than 6 weeks.

Case 4: Complete abortion:

  • There is loss of all fetal and placental tissue.
  • The uterine contractions and bleeding stops.
  • On examination, the uterus is smaller than the period of gestation and the cervix is closed.
  • The pregnancy test is negative.

Incomplete abortion:

  • The presentation is similar to inevitable abortion with vaginal bleeding, cramp-like abdominal pain and partially dilated cervix.
  • In addition, there is loss of some products of conception.

Recurrent abortion:

  • It is defined as an occurrence of three or more successive spontaneous abortions.

questions.text:
The following statements are true/false regarding the Amsterdam II criteria for the diagnosis of HNPCC.
  1. At least three successive generations affected
  2. Tumors should be verified by pathological examination
  3. Three or more relatives with HNPCC-associated cancer, one of whom is a first degree relative of the patient
  4. At least one case diagnosed before age 45 years
  5. Exclude familial adenomatous polyposis
questions.solution:
The correct answer for the above statements is as follows:

  1. False, at-least two successive generations are affected.
  2. True
  3. False, Among three or more relatives with HNPCC -associated cancer, one of them should be a first degree relative of the other two (not with patient)
  4. False, At least one case diagnosed before age 50 years
  5. True

Related Pearl: Amsterdam Criteria II - Revised Criteria for HNPCC

The diagnostic criteria for HNPCC are referred to as the Amsterdam criteria or the 3-2-1-0 rule.

It includes the following:

  • Three or more relatives with HNPCC-associated cancer (colorectal cancer, endometrial cancer, cancer of the small bowel, ureter, or renal pelvis), one of whom is a first-degree relative of the other two
  • At least two successive generations affected
  • At least one case diagnosed before the age of 50 years
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis excluded.
  • Tumors verified by pathologic examination.

All of the above must be applicable for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC to be made in a family.

questions.text: The myogram below shows a slow onset and a longer after-discharge. Which type of reflex does it represent?
questions.solution:
The figure shows the typical myogram recorded from a muscle involved in a crossed extensor reflex. This myogram demonstrates the relatively long latency before the reflex begins and the long after-discharge at the end of the stimulus.

  • When a painful stimulus is applied to the body, the flexor withdrawal and the crossed extensor reflexes are stimulated.
  • About 0.2 to 0.5 seconds after the flexor reflex in one limb, the opposite limb begins to extend. This reflex is called the crossed extensor reflex.
  • After the painful stimulus is removed, the crossed extensor reflex has an even longer period of after-discharge than does the flexor reflex. This prolonged after-discharge results from reverberating circuits among the inter-neuronal cells.

Compare the myograms of a flexor reflex with a crossed extensor reflex.

In the flexor reflex, the contraction occurs immediately after applying the stimulus and the after-discharge is smaller.

questions.text: All the following enzymes are highly active in fasting state, except ____.
questions.solution:
All the options are active in the fasting state, except pyruvate dehydrogenase. Pyruvate dehydrogenase is highly active in the well-fed/high insulin/dephosphorylated state.

The metabolic changes that take place in fasting and fed states are.

Metabolic process

Fasting state/ low insulin-glucagon ratio

Fed state/ high insulin-glucagon ratio

Gluconeogenesis

Increased

Decreased

Glycogenolysis

Increased

Decreased

Ketogenesis

Increased

Decreased

Glycogenesis

Decreased

Increased

Other options:

Option A: Glycogen phosphorylase is the rate-limiting enzyme of glycogenolysis and is decreased in the fed state.

Option B: HMG CoA synthase is the rate-limiting enzyme of ketogenesis and is decreased in the fed state.

Option D: Pyruvate carboxylase is the enzyme involved in gluconeogenesis. It converts pyruvate to oxaloacetate. Its levels is decreased in the fed state.

questions.text: The following image depicts the life cycle of _____________
questions.solution:
The life cycle depicted in the above image is of Loa Loa, the African eye worm.

Life cycle:

The life cycle of loa loa is completed in two hosts, the human acts as the definitive host and flies of the genus chrysops (day biting flies) act as an intermediate host or vector.

In the definitive host:

  • The bite of the infected chrysops during the blood meal cause transmission of the infection to the man. The infective stage which enters the wound is the third stage of the larva.
  • The third stage of the larva enters the subcutaneous tissue and develops into the adult form in 6-12 months.
  • The female adult worms produce sheathed microfilariae which are found in the spinal fluid, urine, sputum, peripheral blood, and lungs.

In the intermediate host:

  • The chrysops ingests the microfilariae.
  • The microfilariae shed the sheaths, and penetrates the fly’s midgut and migrate to the thoracic muscles.
  • The microfilariae then develop into first-stage larvae and subsequently into third-stage infective larvae.
  • The third-stage infective larvae migrate to the fly’s proboscis ready to infect another man.

questions.text: All of the following chemotherapeutic agents can be used in the treatment of succinate dehydrogenase deficient gastrointestinal stromal tumors except?
questions.solution:
Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST), which are succinate dehydrogenase deficient (SDH) do not respond to treatment with imatinib.

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) are mesenchymal tumors originating from the interstitial cells of Cajal, located in the gastrointestinal myenteric plexus.

Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor and is the chemotherapeutic agent of choice in GIST.

However, GISTs that are deficient of succinyl dehydrogenase are resistant to imatinib. In such cases, the following chemotherapeutic agents can be used:

  • Sunitinib
  • Sorafenib
  • Regorafenib
  • Lenvatinib

SDH deficient GIST is commonly seen in Carney’s triad.

Carney’s triad:

  • Gastric GIST (succinyl dehydrogenase deficient)
  • Pulmonary chondroma
  • Extra adrenal paraganglioma

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for scrub typhus during pregnancy and otherwise respectively?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for a case of scrub typhus during pregnancy is azithromycin. For other patients the drug of choice is doxycycline.

An alternative treatment option in pregnant women and patients allergic to doxycycline is chloramphenicol.

questions.text:
The junior resident has administered a large dose of Fentanyl rapidly to the patient and you consequently observe falling O2 saturation, ETCO2 & very limited chest wall movement. The patient is non-responsive to Bag and mask Ventilation. In fact, attempts at Bag and Mask ventilation are encountered with high resistance. Which of the following statements are correct?
  1. The patient is suffering from opioid respiratory depression
  2. A high-pressure Bag and mask ventilation should be used
  3. The patient is suffering from rigid chest wall syndrome
  4. Neuromuscular blockade and mechanical ventilation should be used
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from Rigid Chest wall syndrome caused due to rapid Fentanyl infusion.

This can be differentiated from opioid-induced respiratory depression by the lack of response to Bag and Mask ventilation and the associated high resistance encountered during this. Neuromuscular blockade and mechanical ventilation should be used to treat this.

The mechanisms of rigid chest syndrome are unclear but may be centrally mediated through dopaminergic neurons within the basal ganglia and not due to depression of respiratory drive. Fentanyl may also induce muscle rigidity by activating spinal motor neurons through its actions on the pons.

Other opioid agents that can cause rigid chest syndrome are:-

  • Sufentanil
  • Remifentanil
  • Alfentanil

questions.text: True or false:
questions.solution:
1. Clomiphene citrate is a partial agonist & a potent antagonist of Oestrogen receptor in the pituitary, not a pure agonist.
  2. Clomiphene Citrate increases the amplitude of LH & FSH pulses, not the frequency of the pulses.
  3. The use of Clomiphene citrate is associated with an increased incidence of multiple births, ovarian cysts, hot flashes, and blurred vision.
  4. Clomiphene citrate can be used to induce ovulation in women with a functional hypothalamo-hypophyseal-ovarian system and adequate endogenous estrogen production only.

questions.text: In a 50 kg adult, how much fluid should be given in the first 8 hours for a 2nd-degree burn of 40%, sustained during a camping fire accident?
questions.solution:
As per the recent update :

Percentage of burn x weight (kg) x 2 = volume in ml.

So , substituting the values:

(Percentage of burn) 40 x 50 (weight in kg) x 2 = 4000ml

Volume in ml = 4000

In litres its 4 litres.

Half of fluid is given in first 8 hours  and other half in next 16 hours.

So first 8 hours its 2 litres.

 #RecentUpdate: The initial fluid rate used for burns resuscitation has been updated by the American Burn Association to reflect concerns about over-resuscitation when using the traditional Parkland formula. According to the 10th Edition of ATLS (2018), fluid resuscitation should begin at 2 ml of lactated Ringer’s x patient’s body weight in kg x % TBSA for second and third-degree burns. 

Note:% TBSA of 2nd and 3rd degree burns is calculated for the formula.Not for superficial/1st degree burns.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: The Best imaging modality for determining prognosis in a term neonate with perinatal hypoxia:
questions.solution:
MRI is the best imaging modality for determining prognosis in term neonates with Perinatal Asphyxia. Diffusion-weighted MRI can detect abnormalities within 24 to 48 hours after birth (optimal time is 2 to 3 days), whereas conventional MRI can show abnormalities in the first 3 to 4 days (though optimal time is later during the first week of life.

Findings associated with poor neurodevelopmental outcomes include:

  1. An altered signal at the level of the posterior limb of the internal capsule
  2. Abnormalities of thalami and basal ganglia in term neonates
  3. Abnormalities of white and grey matter at term equivalent age in preterm neonates

Injury to the watershed regions may also be present.

Note: Among prognostic tests in term neonates with perinatal asphyxia, EEG in the first 6 hours showed maximum sensitivity (93%) and specificity (90%).

2. Presinusoidal b. Cirrhosis of liver
3.  Postsinusoidal c. Portal vein thrombosis
4. Posthepatic d. Venoocclusive syndrome
  e. Alcoholic hepatitis
  f. Constrictive pericarditis
questions.solution:
The correct match is:  

  1. Prehepatic               -        c. Portal vein thrombosis
  2. Presinusoidal           -        a. Congenital hepatic fibrosis
  3. Postsinusoidal         -        d. Venoocclusive syndrome
  4. Posthepatic             -        f. Constrictive pericarditis

Classification of portal hypertension:

The causes of portal hypertension are classified under 3 main categories. The prehepatic, hepatic, and posthepatic.

  • The prehepatic includes conditions that affect the portal venous system before it enters the liver.
  • The hepatic includes conditions that affect the liver and are further subcategorized under presinusoidal, sinusoidal, and post sinusoidal. Over 95% of the cases of portal hypertension are due to intrahepatic causes, of which cirrhosis is the most common cause.
  • The posthepatic includes conditions that affect the hepatic veins and venous drainage to the heart.

Related Pearl: Causes of Portal Hypertension

questions.text:
Match column A with Column B:
Column A Column B
  1. Tamoxifen
 A.  Concentric Visual Field Defects
  1. Vigabatrin
 B. Bluish Vision
  1. Topiramate
 C. Choroidal Effusion & Angle-closure Glaucoma
  1. Tadalafil
 D. Iridocyclitis
  E. Crystalline Maculopathy
  F. Bulls Eye Maculopathy
questions.solution:
Column A Column B
Tamoxifen Crystalline Maculopathy
Vigabatrin Concentric Visual Field Defects
Chloroquine Bulls Eye Maculopathy
Tadalafil Bluish Vision
Rifabutin + Clarithromycin/Fluconazole Iridocyclitis
Topiramate Choroidal Effusion & Angle-closure Glaucoma

The antiseizure drug topiramate can cause choroidal effusions leading to angle-closure glaucoma.

Tamoxifen can cause crystalline maculopathy while vigabatrin can cause progressive and permanent bilateral concentric visual field constriction.

In the retinal pigment epithelium, accumulation of chloroquine(due to drug melanin binding) causes a toxic retinal lesion known as a “bull’s-eye” maculopathy, which is associated with a decrease in visual acuity.

The PDE5 inhibitors sildenafil, vardenafil, and tadalafil also mildly inhibit PDE6, which controls the levels of cyclic GMP in the retina causing a bluish haze or light sensitivity.

Rifabutin, if used in conjunction with clarithromycin or fluconazole for the treatment of Mycobacterium avium complex opportunistic infections in HIV-positive persons, is associated with iridocyclitis and even hypopyon.

questions.text: The arterial blood gas analysis of an unconscious man showed pH- 6.9, HCO3- 13 mEq/L, paCO2- 68 mmHg. The acid-base status of this patient is best described as:

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis with partial renal compensation

questions.solution:
According to the ABG analysis provided, the patient has a mixed acid-base disorder with simultaneous respiratory and metabolic acidosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: A pH of 6.9 signifies acidosis.

Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 13 mEq/L, along with a low pH it signifies metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: pCO2 is 68 mmHg indicating co-existing respiratory acidosis. The direction of pCO2 change is the same as that of pH change suggesting that this is a mixed acid-base disorder.

Step 4: The expected compensatory change in pCO2 in the metabolic acidosis calculated using Winter's formula would be:

pCO2 = [1.5xHCO3-] + 8 ± 2 = 26 - 30 mmHg

The actual pCO2 measure is very high (68 mmHg) compared to the estimated range of 26 - 30 mmHg indicating the presence of simultaneous metabolic and respiratory acidosis.

Note- If this was a case of uncompensated acidosis, either the bicarbonate or the pCO2 values would have been within the normal limits. 

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis
Acute

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

questions.text:
Arrange the sequence of steps in leukocyte migration:

a. Stable adhesion

b. Integration activation by chemokine

c. Rolling

d. Migration through endothelium
questions.solution:
The journey of leukocytes from the vessel lumen to the tissue is a multistep process that is mediated and controlled by adhesion molecules and cytokines called chemokines.

This process can be divided into sequential phases:

  1. In the lumen:
    • Margination
    • Rolling (selectin-mediated) (Option C)
    • Activation of integrins (cytokine-mediated) (Option B)
    • Adhesion (integrin-mediated) to the endothelium (Option A)

Vascular endothelium in its normal, unactivated state does not bind circulating cells or impede their passage. In inflammation, the endothelium is activated and can bind leukocytes.

    2. Migration across the endothelium and vessel wall: Diapedesis (Option D)

    3. Migration in the tissues toward a chemotactic stimulus

questions.text:
The causative agents of overwhelming postsplenectomy infection (OPSI) are:
  1. Neisseria meningitidis
  2. Streptococcus pneumoniae
  3. Haemophilus influenzae
  4. Capnocytophaga canimorsus
questions.solution:
All the above-given organisms are causative agents of OPSI.

Prophylaxis:

Immunization and antibiotics have been recommended for preventing opportunistic infections following splenectomy.

Immunization:

Vaccines against pneumococcus, meningococcus and H.influenzae are usually given to prevent OPSI.

  • Pneumococcal vaccine is administered in patients >2years of age. It is repeated every 5 years.
  • Meningococcal vaccine is repeated also every 5 years.
  • H. influenzae type B vaccine is administered irrespective of age. It should be administered 2 weeks before elective surgery or immediately after surgery and before discharge. Given every year.

The CDC (Centers for disease control and prevention) recommends the following vaccines for adults with asplenia.

Vaccine Recommendation

Tetanus (Td/Tdap)

 One dose every 10 years
Human papillomavirus

Three doses for women ≤26 years of age or men ≤21 years of age (0, 2, 6 months)
Measles, mumps, rubella One or two doses  
Varicella Two doses (0, 4-8 weeks)  
Zoster One dose  
Influenza One dose annually  
Pneumococcal polysaccharide One or two doses  
Hepatitis A

Two doses (0, 6-12 months or 0, 6-18 months)
Hepatitis B  

Two or Three doses (0, 1-2 months, 4-6 months)
Meningococcal One dose

Antibiotics:

In children, prophylaxis with penicillin for at least 2 years after splenectomy is usually given.

Related Pearl: Overwhelming Post-splenectomy Infection (OPSI)

It is the most common fatal infection following splenectomy. 

Certain components called opsonins attach to the encapsulated organisms, and then they are delivered to the spleen, where their uptake is facilitated by receptors present on the surface of splenic phagocytes. After splenectomy, this defence mechanism is lost leaving patients susceptible to infection from these bacteria.

Most common within 2-3 years following splenectomy. 

Causative agents: Usually capsulated organisms like

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus species
  • Salmonella species
  • Capnocytophaga canimorsus, implicated in OPSI as a result of dog bites

Clinical features

  • Prodromal features like fever, chills, sore throat, malaise, diarrhea, and vomiting
  • Rapid progression to hypotension, disseminated intravascular coagula­tion, respiratory distress, coma, and death within hours of presen­tation
  • High-grade bacteremia with no identifiable foci of infection
  • Poor response to antibiotics

If an elective splenectomy is planned, prophylactic vaccinations against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) must be given atleast 2 weeks before the elective surgery.

In case of an emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to casualty after falling from a balcony. Based on the CT scan finding provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above axial CT shows a hyperdense lentiform (biconvex) opacity, consistent with an epidural hematoma, which is a collection of blood between the inner surface of the skull and the outer periosteal layer of the dura mater, typically following a history of trauma. The characteristic biconvex shape arises due to the limited ability of blood to expand within the fixed attachment of periosteal dura to the cranial sutures. If bleeding is significant, it may lead to a mass effect with herniation. 

Additionally, a swirl sign may be present, representing acute blood extravasation into a hematoma (extradural/subdural), showing fresh, unclotted blood with lower attenuation than the clotted blood (which is of a higher attenuation), highlighting the need for surgical intervention.

The following CT image depicts a swirl sign:

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A patient presents to OPD with complaints of an assault. On examination, a scab is noted that is brownish-black in color. Which of the following is the most probable time since the injury?
questions.solution:
The presence of a scab that is brownish-black in color indicates that the injury probably occurred 2 to 3 days prior.

Abrasion types:

  • Linear abrasions (scratches): Caused by relative movement of a pointed object on the skin. It leaves a clean area at the start and tags at the end.
    • e.g. nail, thorn, or the point of a sword or knife.
  • Grazed abrasions (sliding /scrapping/grinding abrasion): Caused by relative movement of a rough surface on a wide area of skin.
    • known as brush burns.
    • e.g. fall, a victim being dragged on the ground, road traffic accidents.
  • Impact abrasions (imprint abrasions): Caused by the impact of a rigid hard rough surface over a localized area of the skin, without any movement
    • e.g. fingernails, tires, grills, bicycle chains, or bite marks.
  • Friction abrasions (pressure abrasion): Caused by pressure upon the skin with an agent with a smooth surface, accompanied by movement.
    • e.g. ligature marks around the neck in hanging, strangulation.
  • Patterned abrasion: Caused by impact abrasion or pressure abrasion, reproducing the pattern of the object causing it

Note: Grazed abrasion is the most common type of abrasion.

 

Note: The answer cannot be option D as scab usually falls off by 7th day. So, amongst the given options, the best answer is 2-3 days.

Related Pearl: Age of bruise and abrasion

Bluish black/ brown Hemosiderin 4th day

Reddish brown 2-3 days

questions.text: The motility shown in the time-lapse video given below is seen in:
questions.solution:
The video shows swarming motility of the bacterial growth on a solid agar plate, which is seen in pseudomonas aeruginosa.

The swarming type of motility is exhibited by:

Gram positive bacilli:

  • Clostridium septicum
  • Bacillus cereus

Gram negative bacilli:

  • Proteus mirabilis
  • Proteus vulgaris
  • Salmonella
  • Pseudomonas

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a strict aerobe, gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive bacteria that shows swarming motility. They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include pyorubin (Red), pyomelanin (Brown). It shows a positive oxidase reaction and is non-lactose fermenting in nature.

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include-

  • Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • Pneumonia and sepsis in cystic fibrosis
  • Wound infection and sepsis in burns
  • Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis/ Jacuzzi syndrome is a type of folliculitis, occurring after hot tub exposure
  • Shanghai fever is a febrile illness that manifests as severe enteric disease, sepsis with invasive disease.
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum

Pathogenesis - It is an obligate aerobe that exerts its pathogenicity by the production of diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer. Breach in primary body defenses as in burns predisposes to Pseudomonas infection.

Clinical features - It is characterized by blue-green pus. It is notorious for being resistant to antimicrobials and antiseptics and hence is a frequent contaminant in hospital samples. Repeated isolation and associated clinical features should prompt the diagnosis of Pseudomonas.

Diagnosis - It grows well on most media and pigment production makes its identification easy. Species identification is made possible by biochemical tests - arginine hydrolysis and oxidase reaction. 

Related Pearl: Types of motility of microorganisms

questions.text:
Arrange from the sensors to effector the following components of Light reflex pathway:

A. Edinger Westphal Nucleus

B. Pretectal Nucleus

C. Ciliary Ganglion

D. Short Ciliary Nerves
questions.solution:
Retina-Optic Nerve-Pretectal Nucleus-Edinger Westphal Nucleus- Ciliary Ganglion- Short ciliary Nerves-Sphincter Pupillae.

Pupillary light reflex pathway:

  • First neurons (sensory) connects each retina with both pretectal nuclei in the midbrain at the level of the superior colliculi.
  • Second neurons (internuncial) connects each pretectal nucleus to both Edinger–Westphal nuclei.
  • Third neurons (preganglionic motor) connects the Edinger–Westphal nucleus to the ciliary ganglion.
  • Fourth neurons (postganglionic motor) leaves the ciliary ganglion and pass in the short ciliary nerves to innervate the sphincter pupillae.

questions.text: A 3 weeks old infant was brought to the hospital with a history of recurrent non-bilious vomiting. On examination, an olive-shaped lump was palpable in the epigastrium, and on test feeding, visible peristalsis was found moving from left to right in the upper abdomen. USG was done, which revealed a measurement of 6 mm as marked in the image below. After establishing the diagnosis and further assessment of serum electrolyte levels, D5/1⁄2NS  with added KCl was started at the rate of 150 mL/Kg per day. After 24 hours, the urine output is 1.8 cc/Kg/hr,  and serum bicarbonate level is 37 mEq/L. Other electrolytes have returned to normal range. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Increase the rate of fluid resuscitation to 200 ml/Kg/day
Stop fluid resuscitation and start formula feed or breast milk

questions.solution:
The next best step in management is to continue fluid resuscitation as the urine output is 1.8 cc/Kg/hr (should be >2 cc/Kg/hr) and the serum bicarbonate is 37 mEq/L  (should be <30 mEq/L) which indicates that the rehydration is not achieved and the metabolic abnormality is not yet fully corrected.

The above clinical scenario and the USG showing the pyloric thickness of 6mm ( ≥4 mm) are suggestive of Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS). 

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis:

  • As the name suggests, the condition is seen in infants and is characterized by progressive thickening of the pylorus muscle eventually resulting in gastric outlet obstruction.
  • Infants between 2-8 weeks of age present with projectile non-bilious vomiting.
  • Clinically, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting.
  • Male: Female ~ 5:1

Diagnosis:

The investigation of choice is ultrasonography.

The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis is a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm.

Metabolic abnormality:

  • Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality: Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.
  • Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-).
  • Kidneys try to compensate alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3-. However, loss of sodium stimulates the secretion of aldosterone through the RAAS pathway.
  • The aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for K+ and H+ ions.
  • Loss of potassium ions leads to the development of hypokalemia.
  • Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in aciduria. It is called paradoxical aciduria, since the body initially lost H+ ions due to loss of HCl, and instead of compensating that loss, the body is losing more H+ ions through urine.

Management:

The child should be rehydrated and the metabolic abnormality has to be corrected before proceeding to surgery.

Fluid Resuscitation:

  • Fluid resuscitation should be done with 5% dextrose and 0.45% saline (D5/1⁄2NS) with added potassium of 2 to 4 mEq/kg over 24 hours at a rate of approximately 150 to 175 mL/kg per 24 hours.
  • The urine output should be monitored and the electrolyte levels must be checked every 6 hours.
  • To ensure that rehydration has occurred, the urine output should be >2 cc/Kg/hr.
  • The markers of adequate resuscitation include: serum bicarbonate (<30 mEq/L), chloride (>100 mmol/L), and potassium (4.5–6.5 mmol/L).

Surgery:

  • The surgical procedure of choice is Ramstedt pyloromyotomy, where the pylorus muscle is cut leaving the mucosa intact.

Related Pearl: Potential adverse reactions to drugs administered in infants

Drug Side effect
Oxygen Retinopathy of prematurity, bronchopulmonary dysplasia
Chloramphenicol Gray baby syndrome, bone marrow suppression
Vitamin K analogs Jaundice
Tetracycline Enamel hypoplasia
Sodium bicarbonate Intraventricular hemorrhage
Amphotericin Anuric renal failure
Indomethacin Oliguria, hyponatremia, intestinal perforation
Aminoglycosides Deafness, renal toxicity
Erythromycin Pyloric stenosis
Morphine Hypotension, urine retention

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following stages of death as given by Kubler and Ross from earliest to last:

A. Bargaining

B. Acceptance

C. Depression

D. Anger
questions.solution:
The correct order is:

  • Denial
  • Anger
  • Bargaining
  • Depression
  • Acceptance

 

Related Pearl: The 5 stages of grief model by Kübler-Ross

  • Denial - Patients may become numb and dazed at the news of their own imminent death and refuse to accept the diagnosis. 
  • Anger - Patients may get angry towards God or themselves. 
  • Bargaining - Patients may start to bargain with God or friends and doctors for a cure to buy some more time.
  • Depression - Patients may go into depression.
  • Acceptance - Patients finally accept that their death is inevitable and make further preparations (eg., making a will, etc).

questions.text: A newborn needs to be screened for Hearing Loss. The best test that you can recommend for this is:
questions.solution:
Oto Acoustic Emissions are measurements of the response of the outer hair cells to acoustic stimuli. They test the integrity of cochlea.

To measure the OAEs, a probe is placed in the external auditory canal, and tonal or click stimuli are delivered. The OAE generated by the cochlea is measured with a microphone.

Related Pearl: OAEs - Otoacoustic emissions

It is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea.

It is of two types:

  • Spontaneous type- it is generated spontaneously and is present in 50% of normal individuals.
  • Evoked types- also called Kemp echoes or cochlear echoes, are generated in response to sound stimulus and found in all individuals with normal hearing. The two subtypes are transient evoked and distortion product.

The applications are as follows:

  • Screening test for neonates, infants, and small children for deafness due to inner ear causes.
  • Helps to differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- normal OAE indicates normal cochlea and hence retrocochlear pathology in a patient with sensorineural deafness.
  • Early detection of noise-induced hearing loss- since it is generated by outer hair cells that are prone to damage by noise trauma.

questions.text:
Acarbose and Miglitol:
  1. Cause Alpha-glucosidase inhibition
  2. Increase GLP-1 release
  3. Inhibit SGLT - 2
  4. Contraindicated in stage IV renal failure

choices.text: A B and C are correct
A B and D are correct

questions.solution:
Acarbose, Miglitol & Voglibose reduce the intestinal absorption of starch, dextrin, and disaccharides by inhibiting the action of α-glucosidase in the intestinal brush border.

In addition to this well-known action, they also increase the release of the glucoregulatory hormone GLP-1 into circulation. This may contribute further to their glucoregulatory action.

The most prominent adverse effects are malabsorption, flatulence, diarrhea, and abdominal bloating. The α-glucosidase inhibitors are contraindicated in patients with stage 4 renal failure, and Hypoglycemia may be observed when added to insulin/insulin secretagogue containing regimes.

 

Note:- Acarbose can reduce digoxin absorption while miglitol can reduce propranolol absorption.

questions.text: A 57-year-old female diabetic patient presented with complaints of abdominal pain and weight loss. The lab investigations are suggestive of obstructive jaundice. Serum IgG4 level was found to be elevated. Which of the following statements is false regarding the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: An MRI is likely to reveal a sausage-shaped pancreas

questions.solution:
The clinical features and characteristic elevated serum IgG4 levels are diagnostic of autoimmune pancreatitis. NSAIDs are not used in the treatment.

Patients with autoimmune pancreatitis present with features of obstructive jaundice, weight loss, and mild abdominal pain.

On radiography, the sausage-shaped appearance of the pancreas on the T2 weighted MRI is diagnostic of autoimmune pancreatitis. Serum IgG4 level is considered the best serological marker for AIP. However, in the absence of typical radiographic findings, the elevation of IgG4 is not sufficient to make the diagnosis of AIP.

Most of the cases may resolve spontaneously, however, corticosteroid therapy is still provided as it causes increased remession of AIP. Initially, prednisone is given at a dose of 0.6 mg/Kg for 2 weeks. If there is clinical and radiological improvement, the dose of prednisone is gradually tapered by 5 mg/week.

Shown below is an MRI image of autoimmune pancreatitis showing a sausage-shaped pancreas.

Related Pearl: Laboratory Findings in Acute Pancreatitis

  • Elevated serum amylase and serum lipase
    • Serum amylase level rises immediately and peaks in few hours and returns to normal in 3–5 days
    • Serum amylase level lacks specificity
    • Serum amylase levels do not correlate with the severity of pancreatitis.
    • Serum lipase is more specific, and it is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours later
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia, hypoalbuminemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Elevated serum levels of hepatic enzymes like alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
  • Azotemia, due to prerenal acute renal failure in case of severe fluid loss

Related Pearl: Ranson Prognostic Criteria for Acute Pancreatitis

Ranson's prognostic criteria at presentation
Parameter Non-gallstone pancreatitis Gallstone pancreatitis
Age >55 years >70 years
Blood glucose level >200 mg/dL >220 mg/dL
White blood cell count >16,000 cells/mm3 >18,000 cells/mm3
Serum LDH level >350 IU/L  >400 IU/L
Serum Aspartate aminotransferase level  >250 IU/L  >250 IU/L

 

Ranson's prognostic criteria after 48 hours of admission
Parameter Non-gallstone pancreatitis Gallstone pancreatitis 
Hematocrit fall
 >10% >10%
Serum calcium level <8 mg/dL <8 mg/dL
Base deficit >4 mEq/L >5 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen level increase 

≥5 mg/dL despite IV fluid hydration

 ≥2 mg/dL despite IV fluid hydration
Fluid sequestration
  >6 L  >4 L
PaO2  <60 mm Hg  Not available

Ranson score ≥3 defines severe pancreatitis.

Score Interpretation

  • 0 to 2 points: 0% to 3% mortality
  • 3 to 4 points: 15% mortality
  • 5 to 6 points: 40% mortality
  • 7 to 11: nearly 100% mortality

questions.text: A 6-year-old male presented with progressive gait disturbance and impaired vision. T2 weighted MRI is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above T2 weighted MRI shows an increased signal of the peritrigonal regions extending across the splenium of the corpus callosum, which is characteristic of the X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy.

The condition is usually seen in boys between 5 - 10 years of age. It is the most common leukodystrophy of children

It is caused due to the inflammatory demyelination of the deep white matter involving the splenium and peritrigonal white matter and progressing to the corticospinal tracts and visual and auditory pathways. The inflammation is caused due to the accumulation of VLCFA.

As a result the children present with learning difficulties, behavioral problems, progressive disturbance in gait and impaired vision.

Lorenzo’s oil may delay disease progression

Radiological features:

On MRI, there is signal abnormality (Increased signal on T2WI and low signal on T1WI) posteriorly, involving the peritrigonal region and extending to the splenium. Marginal enhancement is usually seen at the leading edge due to the active inflammation.

Imaging findings of other options:

The pattern of signal abnormality on MRI of various demyelinating diseases is depicted in the image below:

questions.text: Along the course of the lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh, at which of the following sites is the nerve commonly injured leading to meralgia paresthetica?

choices.text: In the abdominal cavity, as the nerve travels across the pelvis
Lateral to the anterior superior iliac spine

questions.solution:
The most common site of injury to the lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh is deep to the inguinal ligament.

An injury to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh (a.k.a lateral femoral cutaneous nerve) leads to pain and paresthesia over the anterolateral region of the thigh, a condition called meralgia paresthetica.

The nerve may be injured at three sites along its course:

  1. Close to the vertebral column.
  2. In the abdominal cavity as it travels across and leaves the pelvis.
  3. By entrapment, at the site where it leaves the pelvis. (most common).

It leaves the pelvis by piercing the inguinal ligament or by going deep to the inguinal ligament, medial (not lateral) to the anterior superior iliac spine. Hip extension causes an increase in the angulation of the nerve and tenses it.

questions.text: True statement regarding the targets/objectives of the campaign whose logo is shown below:

choices.text: Prevention of gender-biased sex selective elimination

questions.solution:
Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao - “Save the daughter, educate the daughter” is a campaign of the Government of India that aims to generate awareness and improve the efficiency of welfare services intended for girls.

The objectives of BBBP are:

  • To prevent gender-biased sex-selective elimination
  • To ensure survival and protection of the girl child
  • To ensure education and participation of the girl child

The targets of this campaign are:

  1. Improve the Sex Ratio at Birth (SRB) in selected gender critical districts by 2 points in a year.
  2. Reduce Gender differentials in Under Five Child Mortality Rate from 7 points in 2014 to 1.5 points per year
  3. At least a 1.5 % increase per year of Institutional Deliveries.
  4. At least a 1% increase per year of 1st Trimester ANC Registration.
  5. Increase enrolment of girls in secondary education to 82% by 2018-19.
  6. Provide functional toilets for girls in every school in selected districts.
  7. Improve the Nutrition status of girls - by reducing the number of underweight and anemic girls under 5 years of age.
  8. Ensure universalization of ICDS, girls’ attendance and equal care monitored, using joint ICDS NHM Mother-Child Protection Cards.
  9. Promote a protective environment for Girl Children through the implementation of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act 2012.
  10. Train Elected Representatives/ Grassroot functionaries as Community Champions to mobilize communities to improve CSR and promote Girl’s education.

questions.text: The image below shows changes in the partial pressure of oxygen and carbon dioxide as blood flows from the arterial end to the venous end of the pulmonary capillaries. Which graph best depicts the normal relationship between the PO2 (red line) and PCO2 (blue line) during resting conditions?
questions.solution:
The first graph best depicts the normal relationship between the Po2 and Pco2 during resting conditions as blood flows from the arterial end to the venous end of the pulmonary capillaries. 

Under resting conditions:

  • By the time the blood flows through one-third of the pulmonary capillaries, it gets saturated with O2 and only little additional O2  enters the blood during the latter two-thirds of its transit. The uptake of oxygen is indicated by the red line in the above image. Not that Po2 (indicated by the red line).
  • Initially rises and reaches a plateau after one-third of transit.
  • The Pco2 (indicated by the blue line) is initially 45 mmHg at the arterial end. As the blood travels one-third distance of the pulmonary capillary, almost all the CO2 diffuses out of the pulmonary capillaries into the alveoli. As it reaches one-third of the distance, the Pco2 drops to 40 mmHg which is equal to the Pco2 of alveolar air.

 

Thus both CO2 and O2 reach their respective stable levels almost simultaneously and at the early part of the blood flow from the arterial end to the venous end of the pulmonary capillaries which is represented correctly in the first image.

questions.text:
Arrange the following events of normal labor in the sequence of their occurrence from earliest to latest:

1. Restitution
2. Delivery of the shoulders and trunk
3. Crowning
4. Engagement
5. External rotation
6. Internal rotation of occiput
7. Delivery of the head by extension
8. Flexion
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events which occur during the normal labor (from earliest to latest) are as follows:

  • Engagement
  • Descent
  • Flexion
  • Internal rotation of occiput anterior to 2/8th of the circle and simultaneous rotation of the shoulders to 1/8th of the circle.
  • Crowning
  • Delivery of head by extension
  • Restitution
  • External rotation
  • Delivery of shoulders and trunk by lateral flexion

questions.text: Which disease is transmitted by the insect depicted below?
questions.solution:
The image given is that of a sandfly, which is the vector for Kala Azar.

It is controlled by synthetic pyrethroids (Permethrin), as it is becoming increasingly resistant to DDT, Malathion and Propoxur.

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards.
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

questions.text: All of the following are first-line therapeutic agents used in medical management of endometriosis, except:
questions.solution:
GnRH agonists are used as second-line therapeutic agent in medical management of endometriosis.

Medical management of endometriosis:

  • First-line: NSAIDs, low dose oral contraceptives and progestins for 3 to 6 months.
  • Second-line: If first-line therapy fails. Includes High dose progestins, danazol, and GnRH agonists.

Surgical treatment for endometriosis:

It is indicated in large endometriomas of >3 cm in diameter.

  • Definitive therapy: Total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with destruction and/or removal of all peritoneal endometriotic implants and adhesions.
  • Fertility preserving therapy: Destruction and/or removal of all peritoneal endometriotic implants and adhesions through a laparoscopic approach or laparotomy.

questions.text: The given image shows the various curves obtained for three different screening tests (A, B, C) employed on a population. Which of the following represents the correct match with respect to the Receiver-Operator-Curve (ROC) obtained in each of them?
questions.solution:
The correct match is A – 2, B – 1, C – 3.

The curves obtained mean the following:

  • A – There are some false negatives and some false positives as shown below. Therefore, the area under the curve is around 0.7 to 0.8. The ROC curve would thus be as shown in Image 2.
  • B – There are almost nil false positives or negatives. The test completely differentiates between healthy and diseased. Thus, the area under the ROC would be close to 0.9 to 1 as shown in Image 1.
  • C – The test does not differentiate between healthy and diseased people at all. The area under the curve for such tests would be 0.5 as represented by Image 3.

Note:

The ROC curve is a fundamental tool for diagnostic test evaluation. In a ROC curve the true positive rate (Sensitivity) is plotted in function of the false positive rate (100-Specificity) for different cut-off points of a parameter. Each point on the ROC curve represents a sensitivity/specificity pair corresponding to a particular decision threshold. The area under the ROC curve (AUC) is a measure of how well a parameter can distinguish between two diagnostic groups (diseased/normal).

questions.text: Consider the following statements regarding Screening Tests and mark True or False:
questions.solution:
• Screening tests are indeed applied upon healthy Population
  • Screening tests are to be applied only for diseases that are an important health problem in the population and have an effective treatment available.
  • Screening tests cannot be used as a basis for treatment and need a diagnostic test to be performed for confirmation of the diagnosis
  • The initiative for a screening test comes from the investigator for a screening test as the test is generally applied upon apparently healthy individuals who do not have complaints.
  • The most common neonatal disease screened is neonatal hypothyroidism and the sample for that is indeed umbilical cord blood.

Screening tests are done on apparently healthy individuals, the results of the test are relatively inaccurate, the tests are based on one criterion.

Features of a screening test:

Done On Apparently healthy
Applied On Groups, Population
Test Results Arbitrary, Final
Based On One Criterion ( Cut off )
Cost Relatively Cheaper
Time Taken Relatively Rapid
Accuracy Relatively Inaccurate
Basis for treatment   Can't be used as the basis
Initiative from Investigator

Screening tests for a condition are recommended in the following conditions:

  • Early diagnosis can change the disease course.
  • The disease should have an asymptomatic stage.
  • The disease should have a test for the diagnosis and treatment of the disease.
  • The natural history of the disease should be well known.

questions.text: The image below shows cardiac output and venous return curves in relation to the right atrial pressure. A represents a normal condition, while points B, C, and D denote the changes occurring in cardiac output and right atrial pressure immediately, 1 min, and several weeks after opening the AV fistula. Which of the graphs correspond to a rise in mean systemic filling pressure (Psf) to 9mmHg due to the constriction of veins and arteries?
questions.solution:
Graph C corresponds to the rise in mean systemic filling pressure to 9 mmHg, which occurs about 1 minute after the opening of AV fistula.

The ascending curve is the cardiac output curve, while the downsloping descending curve is the venous return curve.

The mean systemic filling pressure is indicated on the X-axis and is represented by the right atrial pressure at which the venous return becomes zero.

In the graph, it can be seen that the venous return curves of A (red-colored) and B (black colored) touch the X-axis at +7 mmHg, which is the normal mean systemic filling pressure. 1 minute after, it is 9 mmHg, while after several weeks, it further rises to 12 mmHg.

Immediately after opening the AV fistula:

  • The changes are represented by the cardiac and venous return curves (black coloured) that cross at point B.
  • Large reduction in the resistance to venous return causes sudden rotation of the venous return curve upward.
  • As the peripheral resistance falls, the heart can pump the blood more easily. Hence, there is only a slight increase in the cardiac output curve.
  • The right atrial pressure increases from 0 to +3 mmHg.

1 minute after the opening of AV fistula:

  • The changes are represented by the cardiac and venous return curves (blue coloured) that cross at point C.
  • The sympathetic activity begins which causes further rise in cardiac output curve and increase in right atrial pressure to 4 mmHg.
  • Due to the constriction of all veins and arteries, the mean systemic filling pressure Psf rises from 7 mmHg to 9 mmHg.

Several weeks after opening of AV fistula:

  • The changes are represented by the cardiac and venous return curves (green coloured) that cross at point D.
  • Reduced arterial pressure and sympathetic stimulation causes decreased urine output and salt and water retention.
  • As a result, the blood volume increases which causes further rise in mean systemic filling pressure Psf from 9 mmHg to 12 mmHg.
  • Increased workload on the heart causes hypertrophy of the cardiac muscle which further increases the cardiac output curve, and the right atrial pressure increases to 6 mmHg.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency with complaints of the persistent erection of the penis for the past 2 hours even though he doesn't feel sexually stimulated The drug of choice for treatment of this is:
questions.solution:
Phenylephrine is the drug of choice and first-line treatment of priapism because the drug has almost pure alpha-agonist effects and minimal Beta activity.

Short-term priapism, i.e < 6 hours and drug-induced priapism are treated with intracavernosal injection of phenylephrine. Vital signs should be monitored, and compression should be applied to the area of injection to help prevent hematoma formation.

Oral Phenylephrine can also be - 10 to 20 mg every 4 hours as needed, but it is not as effective or as rapid.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male has an abrupt onset right-sided body weakness and slurred speech. On examination in the emergency department 1.5 hours after onset of symptoms, the patient has moderate weakness of right deltoid, triceps, and the intrinsic hand muscles and a mild right foot drop. His blood pressure is 190/112 mm Hg, with a heart rate of 80 beats per minute. CT scan was taken, which revealed the finding as shown in the image below. Which of the following is an appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Administration of IV recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA)

questions.solution:
The next step is to lower blood pressure by administration of intermittent doses of IV labetalol.

The clinical features are suggestive of acute ischemic stroke. The CT scan shows the insular ribbon sign (red arrow), suggestive of left MCA infarction.

The Insular ribbon sign, also called loss of insular ribbon sign, is defined as the loss of the normal grey and white matter differentiation in the lateral margin of the insular cortex (insular ribbon). It is an early CT sign of middle cerebral artery infarction.

Since the patient presented within the 4.5 hr window, the mainstay of management would be IV rtPA administration. However, rtPA is contraindicated if the blood pressure is >185/110 mmHg due to the risk of haemorrhage.

Therefore, before the administration of rtPA, the blood pressure has to be reduced by administering intermittent doses of IV labetalol or nicardipine. If the diastolic blood pressure is >140 mmHg, then, sodium nitroprusside infusion may be given to lower blood pressure.

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text:
Assertion: CMV infection cannot be transmitted through FFP transfusion.
Reason: FFP stored at -18 Degree Celsius.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both the assertion and reason are true but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false
Assertion is false but the reason is true
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution:
Although FFP is acellular, sometimes it can be contaminated with a substantial number of WBCs and platelets. This possesses a risk of transmission of CMV infection and it can be reduced by using leukoreduction techniques.

FFP is indeed stored at -18 Degree Celsius.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient is undergoing focused parathyroidectomy. After removal of parathyroid adenoma, the surgeon can confirm that there are no hyperactive parathyroid tissue left if the intraoperative PTH,
questions.solution:
A drop of intraoperative PTH to <50% of the preoperative PTH in 10 minutes suggests a single-gland disease. This is known as Miami criteria.

About 80% of the patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have single adenoma, and therefore undergo a focused or minimally invasive parathyroidectomy, where the localized abnormal parathyroid gland is removed. Once the gland is removed, the surgeon can ensure that there is no other hyperactive gland remaining by performing an intraoperative PTH assay.

It is based on the principle that the half-life of the PTH is 3-5 minutes. In a single-gland disease, once the gland is removed the PTH levels should drop to <50% of the preoperative PTH level within 10 minutes.

However, if there is no drop in PTH level, then a multi-gland disease is suspected and the surgery is converted to a bilateral neck exploration.

questions.text: Which of the following candida species on routine culture media produces only yeast cells and without formation of pseudohyphae?
questions.solution:
C. glabrata on culture media produces only the yeast cells without the formation of pseudohyphae.

On culture media, the candida species grow as oval budding yeast cells. In all candida species except candida glabrata, the buds may elongate leading to the formation of pseudohyphae, which are constricted at septations between the cells.

C. albicans is considered as dimorphic as in addition to the yeast and pseudohyphae, it also produces the true hyphae or germ tubes when incubated in the serum for 90 minutes at 37°C.

The morphological forms of the candida species can be summarized in the table below:

Morphological form Candida species
Yeast cells only C. glabrata
Yeasts and pseudohyphae C. parapsilosis, C. tropicalis, C. guilliermondii, and C. dubliniensis 
Yeast, pseudohyphae and true hyphae C. albicans

questions.text: A middle-aged woman comes to your clinic due to recurrent episodes of cough productive of large amounts of sputum for 2 years. She is a non-smoker. Lung examination reveals wheezes with crackles bilaterally. A transverse section of the CT lung is given in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of repeated chest infections with the presence of large amounts of sputum in a non-smoker point to the diagnosis of bronchiectasis. The CT scan showing the signet ring sign is specific for bronchiectasis.

Bronchiectasis refers to the irreversible dilatation of bronchi due to recurrent cycles of infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. Development of the disease requires an infectious insult in combination with impaired bacterial clearance (eg, impaired immune defenses, structural airway defect).

Bronchiectasis is commonly associated with Kartagener syndrome, cystic fibrosis, and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis.

Clinically, patients present with persistent productive cough and production of thick tenacious sputum. On examination, there will be clubbing, wheeze, and crackles.

A chest X-ray shows tram track appearance due to the dilated airways. Chest CT is the best method for the diagnosis of bronchiectasis. CT findings include:

  • Tram track appearance
  • Signet ring sign
  • Lack of bronchial tapering
  • Tree-in-bud pattern - It occurs due to the thickening of the dilated airways along with the inspissated secretions.
  • Cysts originating from the bronchial wall (pronounced in cystic bronchiectasis)

The image given below shows the signet ring sign (arrows) seen in bronchiectasis:

 

Other options:

Option A: Pulmonary tuberculosis is an infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Patients often present with chronic cough and hemoptysis along with low-grade fever, and weight loss. On CT, Ghon focus, Ranke complex, nodal calcifications, cavities, and hilar/paratracheal lymphadenopathy can be seen.

The image given below shows cavities in pulmonary tuberculosis:

 

Option C: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) typically will be smokers with exertional dyspnea, and cough with productive sputum. Lung hyperinflation (emphysema) and airflow obstruction are characteristic of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease on imaging. 

Option D: Patients with bronchial asthma present with symptoms such as wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and cough usually on exposure to triggering agents. On CT, bronchial wall thickening, mucus plugging, decreased lung attenuation, and gas trapping is seen.

Related Pearl: Investigation of Choice in Respiratory Diseases

Disease Investigation of choice
Interstitial lung disease HRCT
Bronchiectasis HRCT
Pulmonary embolism CT Pulmonary Angiography > Ventilation-Perfusion Scan
Calcification CT
Solitary pulmonary nodule CT > PET
Lung Malignancy CT scan
Superior sulcus tumor MRI scan > CT scan

Related Pearl: Types of Bronchiectasis

Cylindrical/Tubular Saccular/Varicose Cystic
  • Mildest form of bronchiectasis
  • Loss of normal airway tapering
  • Bronchi have a uniform calibre, have parallel walls tram track sign and signet ring sign
  • Further distortion of the airway wall along with more mucous and sputum production
  • Beaded bronchi with interspersed sites of relative narrowing
  • Most severe form of bronchiectasis and least common
  • This form has large air spaces and a honeycombed appearance
  • Air fluid levels present

Related Pearl: Tram Track Appearance in Various Conditions

Tram tracks or tram track signs are medical signs that bear some resemblance to tramway tracks (Railway Track).

1. Pulmonology

  • When found in the lungs, tram tracks are radiologic signs that are usually accompanied by pulmonary edema in cases of congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis.
  • Tram tracks are caused by bronchial wall thickening, and can be detected on a lateral chest X-ray.

2. Nephrology

  • The term "tram tracks" is also used to describe the basement membrane duplication found on light microscopy that is characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I.
  • It is less commonly associated with types II and III.

3. Neurology

  • The term has also been used to describe findings associated with optic nerve sheath meningioma.
  • Tram track-shaped calcifications in the cerebral cortex indicate Sturge-Weber syndrome.

4. Mammary glands:

  • Tram track appearance in mammography/USG indicates Duct Ectasia.

questions.text: NEXUS criteria include all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The ability to rotate the neck actively is not included in NEXUS criteria.

In trauma patients, without the need for radiologic imaging, the decision to discontinue the cervical c-spine collar can be made using the clinical tools namely:

  • National Emergency X-Radiography Utilization Study (NEXUS)
  • Canadian C-spine rule (CCR)

NEXUS criteria: There are five criteria included under NEXUS. If a trauma patient meets all five criteria, then no radiography is required and the cervical c-spine collar may be removed. However, if any one of the criteria is not met then radiography is done to evaluate further.

The NEXUS criteria include:

  1. No posterior midline cervical spinal tenderness
  2. No evidence of intoxication
  3. A normal level of alertness
  4. No focal neurologic deficit
  5. No painful distracting injuries
