questions.text: The following statements are true/false regarding the ADA criteria for the diagnosis of diabetes mellitus.
questions.solution:
The correct answer is as below:

Option a: False: The definition of fasting is no caloric intake for at least 8 hours.

Option b: True

Option c: False: HbA1c  ≥6.5% is an independent criteria for the diagnosis of diabetes mellitus.

Option d: False: The rise in random blood glucose alone is not sufficient for the diagnosis and should be accompanied by the presence of symptoms of diabetes.

Related Pearl: ADA criteria for Diagnosis of Diabetes mellitus

Any one of the following:

  • Symptoms of diabetes plus Random Blood Glucose concentration ≥ 200 mg/dL.
  • Fasting plasma glucose ≥ 126 mg/dL. Fasting is defined as no caloric intake for at least 8 hours.
  • Haemoglobin A1c ≥6.5%
  • 2-hour plasma glucose ≥ 200 mg/dL during an oral glucose tolerance test.

Note: In the absence of unequivocal hyperglycemia and acute metabolic decompensation, these criteria should be confirmed by repeat testing on a different day.

questions.text:
During the rounds in the NICU, you notice a lack of respiratory movements in a neonate. You would classify this as apnoea if:

A. It lasts > 20 seconds

B. Associated with cyanosis

C. Associated with bradycardia

D. Associated with Hypotonia

E. Associated with Hypertonia

choices.text: A, B and D are correct
A, C and E are correct
A, B and C  are correct
B, C and D are correct

questions.solution:
Apnea is defined as the cessation of breathing for longer than 20 sec, or for a shorter duration in the presence of bradycardia or change in skin color (pallor or cyanosis).

Apnea is a pathological cessation of breathing that results in hemodynamic disturbances and merits treatment.

In contrast, Periodic breathing is a normal event in preterm infants, that reflects the respiratory control system immaturity and does not merit any treatment. 30-45% of preterm neonates exhibit periodic breathing pattern characterized by three or more respiratory pauses of greater than 3 seconds duration.

Note:

Significant bradycardia is defined as heart rate <80 bpm and

Significant desaturation is defined as oxygen saturation <80-85%.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the ER after a skateboarding accident during which he had fallen with head hitting the ground first. He has a nasal discharge which has the following appearance on a tissue paper. The investigation of choice for localizing the site is:
questions.solution:
HRCT is the investigation of choice for localizing the site of the leak in CSF rhinorrhea. History of head trauma along with nasal discharge that shows double target sign on tissue paper is consistent with traumatic CSF rhinorrhea.

Though Beta 2-transferrin assay is the best laboratory test for identifying the presence of CSF in the sinonasal fluid it does not provide information regarding the site or laterality of the defect.

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double ring sign or halo sign or target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.

The image below shows the double ring sign in CSF rhinorrhoea:

  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

 

Note: The repeated reappearance of pus immediately after cleaning, in the external auditory canal of patients with acute mastoiditis/coalescent mastoiditis is also referred to as Reservoir sign.

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is cusco's bivalve self retaining vaginal speculum.

Uses:

  • Cusco’s speculum is used for visualization of the cervix and vaginal fornices for any polyps or ectopic pregnancy.
  • To inspect the cervix and prepare pap smear.
  • To visualize cervical os in order to look for any discharge in case of endocervicitis or leakage of liqor in case of PROM.
  • During minor procedures like IUCD insertion or removal, Cauterisation of cervical erosion, colposcopic examination.
  • During endometrial biopsy and cervical punch biopsy.
  • During intrauterine insemination.

 

Other options:

Option a - Sim's double-bladed vaginal speculum

Option c: Doyen’s retractor

Option d: Auvard Speculum

questions.text: The image below shows quantification of the prolapse based on POP-Q system. The stage of pelvic organ prolapse is:
questions.solution:
In the above POP-Q system, the lowest point Bp is 5 cms below the hymen, and is an incomplete prolapse suggesting a stage 3 POP.

The Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification system (POP-Q) is done to objectively quantify the prolapse.

  • The hymen is taken as fixed point.
  • Six sites (points Aa, Ba, C, D, Bp, and Ap), genital hiatus (gh), perineal body (pb), and total vaginal length (Tvl) used for pelvic organ support quantitation.
  • The points are measured using a scaled spatula and are recorded in centimeters, in a grid.
  • If the point is above the hymen, it is recorded with -(negative) sign. If the point is below the hymen, It is recorded with the +(positive) sign.

The image below shows the points measured in the POP-Q system.

Staging of POP:

 

Stage 0 No prolapse
Stage 1 All points are 1 cm above the hymen
Stage 2 The lowest point is within 1 cm of hymen (+/- 1)
Stage 3 Lowest point is more than 1 cm below the hymen (> +1) and incomplete prolapse
Stage 4 Complete prolapse with lowest point equal to TVL-2 

Interpretation of the POP-Q grid given in question:

  • The point A posterior (Ap) and point B posterior (Bp) are 2 cms and 5 cms below the hymen, while the point a anterior (Aa) and point B anterior (Ba) are 3 cms above the hymen.
  • This suggests a posterior vaginal wall prolapse. Also, it is an incomplete prolapse as the anterior vaginal wall is above the hymen.
  • The lowest point is Bp, which is 5 cms below the hymen. Since the lowest point is greater than 1 cm below the hymen and is an incomplete prolapse, the POP is stage 3.

questions.text: Which of the following types of psoriasis cannot be treated with methotrexate?
questions.solution:
Methotrexate can be given in all types of psoriasis except impetigo herpetiformis, also known as acute generalized pustular psoriasis of pregnancy. The drug of choice for impetigo herpetiformis is systemic steroids.

Impetigo herpetiformis typically presents during the last trimester of pregnancy. It may persist until the delivery of the child, however, it may even persist longer. Clinical features include:

  • Characteristic erythematous patches with marginal grouped sterile pustules
  • Flexures affected, symmetrical
  • Centrifugal extension from the inguino-genital region
  • Grouping of areas of pustulation
  • Erosions and crusts may be present
  • Residual reddish-brown pigmentation as healing occurs.
  • Nail, mucosal lesions in tongue, mouth, and oesophagus
  • May be associated with hypothyroidism and hypocalcemia

Below is an image showing annular lesions on the left thigh of a patient with pustular psoriasis of pregnancy. 

The mainstay of treatment is systemic corticosteroids. If unresponsive to corticosteroids, cyclosporine can also be started. Antibiotics like cephalosporins are found to be effective as an additive treatment, even though the pustules are sterile. Narrowband UVB is considered another safe treatment when there is not an adequate response to steroids.

Complications like intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), premature rupture of membranes (PROM), and placental insufficiency are also seen. Death of the mother may occur due to cardiac or renal failure. Recurrence is common.

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for different types of psoriasis

Type Drug of choice
Chronic Plaque Psoriasis Methotrexate
Erythrodermic Psoriasis Methotrexate 
Psoriatic Arthritis Methotrexate / Apremilast
Pustular Psoriasis Acitretin
Psoriasis in HIV patients Acitretin
Impetigo Herpetiformis

1. Systemic Corticosteroids

2. Cyclosporine
Erythrodermic Psoriasis in Pregnancy Systemic Corticosteroids

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding thermoregulatory measures in a <32 weeks Newborn except:

choices.text: Immediate drying with a warm towel
Delivery room temperature of at least 26 degrees Celsius

questions.solution:
The neonate should not be dried immediately at birth. The neonate should be wrapped immediately using polythene bags/ wraps. This bag should not be removed until the neonate is transferred to the NICU and normal temperature is recorded.

The thermoregulation measures advised are:

  • Maintain a delivery room temperature of at least 26°C for all deliveries <32 weeks. Switch off the air conditioner in the delivery room.
  • Prewarm the radiant warmer to 100% heater output for at least 10 minutes prior to delivery.
  • Use polythene bags/ wraps for all neonates <32 weeks gestation.
  • Do not dry the neonate. Do not remove the bag until the neonate is transferred to the NICU and normal temperature is recorded.
  • Cover the head with the plastic bag. Use of hat is recommended.
  • Use a transport incubator to transfer neonates from the Delivery room to NICU.
  • Prewarm the baby boundaries and the transport incubator prior to use.
  • Measure axillary temperature within 10 minutes of NICU admission.

NRP recommends that the temperature of a neonate be maintained between 36.5 °C and 37.5 °C from birth till initial stabilization.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman was diagnosed with asthma 6 months ago and was prescribed inhaled albuterol. For the past six months, she felt generally well and required to use her inhaler only for about four to six times a week when around the pollen. She is a non-smoker and is on no other medication. Which of the following would you advise?
questions.solution:
• Inhaled corticosteroid is the first line of treatment in patients with persistent asthma.
  • Patients with mild, intermittent asthma are treated with a short-acting β2-agonist.
  • However, if the patient requires β2-agonist for more than twice a week (persistent asthma) then the treatment is stepped up by adding a low dose of inhaled corticosteroid, which is given twice daily.
  • Initially a low dose of inhaled corticosteroid, such as beclomethasone is required and the dosage is decreased if the symptoms are controlled after 3 months.
  • If symptoms are not controlled, a long-acting β-agonist (LABA) should be added.

questions.text:
In which of the following is the use of N2O contraindicated:

A.    Air Embolism

B.    Acute Intestinal Obstruction

C.    Pneumothorax

D.    Pneumocephalus

E.    Tympanic Membrane Grafting

choices.text: B, C and D are contraindications

questions.solution:
In gas-filled spaces, N2O diffuses more rapidly than the air (principally nitrogen) diffuses out which increases the pressure within the cavity if the volume of the cavity is rigid.

Hence N2O is contraindicated in:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Acute intestinal obstruction
  • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting

Related Pearl: Unique features of Nitrous oxide

Concentration-effect

  • The blood gas partition coefficient of N2O is 35 times higher than O2 and N2, hence its rapid uptake diminishes its volume and concentrates the remaining anesthetics in the alveolus.

Second-gas effect

  • Concentration-effect of one gas over another is known as the second gas effect
  • Increase in the partial pressure of the 2nd gas (Oxygen and volatile agents) due to the rapid uptake of N2O during induction.

Diffusion hypoxia (Finks effect)

  • Rapid elimination of N2O during recovery causes a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen leading to hypoxia
  • Avoided by using 100% oxygen for 10 minutes during recovery from anesthesia.

Nitrous oxide in gas-filled spaces

  • It diffuses into air-containing cavities more rapidly than air (principally nitrogen) can be absorbed by the bloodstream
  • If the walls surrounding the cavity are rigid, pressure rises instead of volume.

Hence N2O is contraindicated in:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Acute intestinal obstruction
  • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting.

questions.text: All of the following are degenerative dementia except:
questions.solution:
Dementia pugilistica/punch drunk syndrome is post-traumatic dementia, not a degenerative dementia. This occurs in boxers & football players after repeated head trauma over many years. It is characterized by emotional lability, dysarthria, and impulsivity.

Degenerative dementias include:

  • Alzheimer's disease
  • Frontotemporal dementias (e.g., Pick's disease)
  • Parkinson's disease
  • Lewy body dementia
  • Idiopathic cerebral ferrocalcinosis (Fahr's disease)
  • Progressive supranuclear palsy

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding management of acute urinary retention?

choices.text: Coude catheterization is preferred in men with benign prostatic hyperplasia
The tip of the coude catheter should always point to 12 o’clock when inserted
Suprapubic tube should not be inserted due to the risk of bowel injury
If retention is caused due to hematuria, continuous bladder irrigation is done

questions.solution:
Suprapubic tube insertion is one of the modalities in the management of acute urinary retention. The risk of bowel injury is very low as the bladder is fully distended due to the retention of urine.

Acute urinary retention may be seen in men and women but commonly occurs in men with benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Other causes of acute urinary retention include:

  • Diabetic neuropathy
  • Urethral stricture
  • Parkinson’s disease
  • Multiple sclerosis

Management: Acute urinary retention is managed by placing a urinary catheter as early as possible. In patients with BPH, a specialised catheter called coude catheter may be placed. It is a curved catheter and is useful in passing the catheter through the angulation in the prostatic urethra. Once the curved tip enters the bladder, it is maintained at the 12’O o'clock position.

If catheter placement is not successful:

  • If there is a urethral stricture, it is dilated with a cystoscope, guide wires and urethral dilators and a council tip catheter is inserted. Or
  • A suprapubic catheter may be inserted.

If the retention is caused by hematuria:

  • A large three-way catheter with an additional port for fluid inflow is inserted.
  • The fluid is infused, and continuous bladder irrigation is done to prevent clot formation.
  • Note that the fluid should be infused only under gravity, as infusion under high pressure may cause bladder rupture.

questions.text: All are early complications of cataract surgery except:
questions.solution:
Cystoid Macular Edema is a late complication following cataract surgery.

Cystoid macular edema is the collection of fluid between the outer plexiform layer and the inner nuclear layer of the retina centered around the fovea with the formation of tiny cyst-like cavities forming a petaloid pattern on fluorescein angiography.

Fluid may initially accumulate intracellularly in Müller cells,  with subsequent rupture.  Coalescence of smaller cavities may occur over time with subsequent progression to a foveal lamellar hole, with irreversible impairment of central vision.  CMO is a nonspecific manifestation of any type of macular edema.

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Symptoms may include blurring, distortion, and micropsia.
  • Signs:
    • Loss of the foveal depression, thickening of the retina and multiple cysts
    • Optic disc swelling is sometimes present
  • Fluorescein angiography:  A petaloid pattern is seen due to dye accumulation in microcystic spaces in the outer plexiform layer.
  • OCT shows retinal thickening with cystic hyporeflective spaces and loss of the foveal depression.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses belongs to the family filoviridae, and is transmitted as depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ebola virus belongs to the family filoviridae and is transmitted by bats.

Ebola virus:

  • It is the cause of an emerging disease called Ebola virus disease and is widespread in Africa.
  • It belongs to the Filoviridae family.
  • Incubation period: 2 to 21 days.
  • Transmission is through contact with infectious bodily fluids or organs of animals like chimpanzees and monkeys.
  • Human to human transmission is through blood or body fluids of an infected symptomatic person.
  • It can remain in semen for up to 3 months, although sexual transmission has not been reported yet.
  • Symptoms include fever, intense weakness, vomiting, diarrhea, rashes, and, in extreme cases, internal and external bleeding.
  • Ebola virus shows a bowl of spaghetti appearance.
  • The current treatment is mainly supportive.
  • Patients are susceptible to reinfection even after complete cure.

questions.text: A young child developed sudden bouts of vomiting and was brought to the ER.  Her condition rapidly worsened as she developed seizures. She had a history of influenza infection one week ago. The patient's liver biopsy will show ______.
questions.solution:
Severe vomiting in a 5-year-old child, rapidly worsening to seizures, with a history of viral infection (influenza) is suggestive of Reye's syndrome. Hence, liver biopsy will show marked microvesicular steatosis.

Reye's syndrome is a secondary mitochondrial hepatopathy. It is precipitated due to

  • Viral infection (influenza, adenovirus, herpes, coxsackievirus A, Epstein–Barr virus)
  • Salicylate or antiemetic use
  • Inborn error of metabolism such as single enzyme defects of ß oxidation.
  • Toxins

There is an acute onset of vomiting and encephalopathy, rapidly progressing to seizures, coma, and death. There is no jaundice.

Investigations

  • ↑ ALT and AST
  • ↑ Ammonia
  • normal bilirubin
  • Hypoglycemia
  • PT prolonged
  • INR increased
  • Liver biopsy: marked microvesicular steatosis. Necrosis is not seen.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman, who is a known case of carcinoma breast, had blurred vision, nausea and vomiting. After a few weeks,​ the patient developed clumsiness of both hands and imbalance that has led to several falls. MRI revealed cerebellar atrophy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of the patient?
questions.solution:
Serum anti-Yo (PCA1) is assessed to evaluate for paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration.

The presence of gait and limb ataxia and subacute onset of symptoms together with MRI findings of cerebellar atrophy is suggestive of paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration mainly due to extensive degeneration of purkinje cells.

The syndrome occurs due to the antibodies that develop against the neural proteins expressed by the tumors, which cross-react with normal neuronal tissue.

The tumors commonly involved include:

  • Small cell lung cancer
  • Breast carcinoma
  • Ovarian carcinoma
  • Hodgkin’s lymphoma

The anti neuronal antibodies may be detected in the serum and/or CSF.

These antibodies causing cerebellar syndrome include:

Antibodies Tumor associated
Purkinje cell cytoplasmic antibody type 1 (PCA1), also called Anti-yo Carcinoma of the breast, ovary
Antibodies against voltage gated calcium channels (Anti-VGCC) Small cell lung cancer
Anti-Tr (or anti-Delta/Notch-like epidermal growth factor-related receptor [DNER]) Hodgkin’s lymphoma
Anti Metabotropic glutamate receptor 1 (mGluR1) Hodgkin’s lymphoma

questions.text: A 63-year-old is diagnosed with a pituitary mass. The presence of which of the following features is(are) consistent with a diagnosis of pituitary carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The presence of craniospinal or systemic metastases is considered to be a sine qua non of a pituitary carcinoma.

Pituitary carcinoma, like pituitary adenoma, is also associated with the presence of Cellular monomorphism and absence of reticulin network.

questions.text: All of the following cause a decrease in TBG binding of Thyroxine except:
questions.solution:
Tamoxifen causes an increase, not decrease, in TBG binding of Thyroxine.

The clinical relevance of this is that in conditions associated with increased binding to TBG, such as pregnancy, clearance of thyroxine is retarded.

The opposite effect, i.e, rapid clearance is observed when binding to protein is inhibited by certain drugs.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the WHO surgical safety checklist?

choices.text: Consent of the patient is taken in sign in
The time out begins before induction of anesthesia
Surgeon, anesthetist and nurse verbally confirms the patient, site and procedure in time out
The sign out begins before the patient leaves the operating room

questions.solution:
The sign in occurs before induction of anesthesia while the timeout occurs before skin incision.

WHO surgical safety checklist:

WHO has devised a checklist that has to be followed in the operating room, to promote patient safety and to prevent potential errors in surgery.

The potential errors that tend to happen in surgery include:

  • Surgery performed on the wrong patient or on the wrong side
  • Performing a wrong procedure
  • Retained swabs or instruments
  • Miscommunication about the procedure or a change in patient’s condition

The WHO safety checklist aims at preventing such errors by listing certain action points to be taken by the doctors, nurses and anesthetists at three stages, namely the sign in, time out, and sign out.

The checklist of actions to be performed under each stage is shown in the image below:

questions.text: A 40-year-old male was brought to the casualty with multiple stab injuries over the abdomen. He was immediately prepared for emergency surgery and an endotracheal tube was inserted. Following intubation,  capnography was performed and end-tidal CO2 was detected. But his oxygen saturation dropped to 60 and there were no breath sounds audible over the left hemithorax. This is probably because of?
questions.solution:
• Detection of end-tidal CO2 but dropping oxygen saturation and hypoxia with absent breath sounds over the left hemithorax point to endobronchial intubation into the right main bronchus.
  • Endobronchial intubation is first indicated by a sudden rise in peak inspiratory pressure.
  • Capnography and detection of end-tidal CO2 is the surest confirmation for endotracheal intubation but it does not differentiate endotracheal from endobronchial intubation.
  • Signs of endobronchial intubation.
  • Elevated peak inspiratory pressure and other airway pressures
  • Asymmetric chest expansion
  • Unilateral breath sounds
  • Hypoxemia
  • Signs of correct endotracheal intubation:
    • Detection of end tidal CO2 by capnography (SUREST CONFIRMATION)
    • Symmetric chest rise
    • Bilateral breath sounds
    • Absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium
    • Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube
    • Large exhaled tidal volumes
    • Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation
  • During an esophageal intubation, initial end tidal CO2 may be detected due to swallowed air but later becomes zero and there would be absence of breath sounds bilaterally with presence of breath sounds in the epigastrium.

questions.text: The sonography demonstrates:
questions.solution:
The given ultrasonograph demonstrates overlapping skull bones, also known as Spalding sign. 

Option A: Spalding sign

  • The irregular overlapping of cranial bones on one another is due to liquefaction of brain and softening of ligamentous structures supporting the vault.
  • It usually appears 7 days after death

Option B: Roberts sign

  • Earliest sign of IUD - seen within 12 hours of death
  • The presence of gas shadow within the chambers of the heart and in large vessels of the fetus.

Option C: Blair-Hartley/Ball: sign 

  • Hyperextension/hyperflexion of spine with crowding of ribs
  • Usually seen 3-4 weeks after death
Sign Interval (After Death)
Robert sign (gas in great vessels) 12h
Spalding sign (overlapping of skull bones) 1 week
Blair-Hartley / Ball sign (hyperflexion / hyperextension of spine over ovecrowding of ribs) 3-4 weeks

questions.text: What is the approximate weight of the fetus , if the height of the uterus above pubic symphysis is about 35cm and station of head -2?
questions.solution:
Estimation of fetal weight using Johnsons formula:

If station of fetal head is below the ischial spine

  • Fetal weight = (Ht of uterus above pubic symphysis [in cms] – 11) ⨯155

If station of fetal head is at or above ischial spine

  • Fetal weight = (Ht of uterus above pubic symphysis [in cms] – 12) ⨯155

In the given question, the station of head= -2 ,  is Above the ischial spine,

Height of uterus above pubic  symphysis = 35 cm

hence,

Fetal weight = (35-12) ⨯155    = 23⨯155    = 3,565 gm

Approximate weight = 3.5 kg.
